editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p: THE INTEREST Of the≈øe United Provinces. BEING A Defence of the Zeelanders Choice.

Wherein is ≈øhewne,
I. That we ought unanimou≈øly to defend our ≈øelves.
II. That if we cannot, it is better to be under England than France, in regard of Religion, Liberty, E≈øtates, and Trade.
III. That we are not yet come to that extremity, but we may remaine a Republick. And that our Compliance with England is the onely meanes for this.
TOGETHER WITH Severall Remarkes upon the pre≈øent, and Conjectures on the future State of Affaires in Europe, e≈øpecially as relating to this Republick.
By a wellwi≈øher to the Reformed Religion, and the wellfare of the≈øe Countries.
MIDDELBURG,

div.head: A Summary of the en≈øuing Treati≈øe.
div.p: THe PREFACE. Wherein, the occa≈øion and rea≈øon of this Worke. The Authors feares ballanced with others hopes. The nece≈ø≈øity of unanimity for, and duty of ≈øelfe defence.

list.item: SECTION I. The ri≈øe and State of that great Que≈øtion, (viz.) whether upon ≈øuppo≈øal of inability to defend our ≈øelves, it is our INTREST to be under England or France, and the Zeelanders choice of the former.

2. Arguments to prove this choice to be agreable to our true Intre≈øt. The fir≈øt whereof is from our Religious concernements. Wherein is ≈øhewne how great a ≈øupport Religion is to a State, and how greatly it concernes us to ≈øecure our Religion.
3. The plea of France's granting us the liberty of our Religion, con≈øidered.

4. Objections from the danger of lo≈øing our Religion under England; from the Kings being a Papi≈øt, de≈øigning to ≈øet up Popery; the increa≈øe, countenance, and tolleration of Papi≈øts, as all≈øo from his joyning with France again≈øt us, and Church Governement by Bi≈øhops, all an≈øwered.

5. A 2d Argument taken from Liberty. Wherein the different Kinds and degrees of Liberty, under all ≈øorts of Governement, are declared; and the probability of enjoying greater freedome under England than France, argued.
6. The 3d Argument is the pre≈øervation of our E≈øtates; in regard of Soldjers violence, Governors impo≈øitions, Publique Debts by obligation, and Revenues of the Romi≈øh Church.

7. The 4th Argument from Trade. This (viz. Merchandi≈øe and Navigation) our cheife ≈øecular Intre≈øt. And friend≈øhip with England to ≈øecure the ≈øame. England and we Competitors herein, what implyed thereby in point of Intre≈øt, and Inference. The probability of getting more, as all≈øo enjoying the ≈øame with greater Peace under France, with other Arguments, largely debated; and the contrary evinced under England.

8. Severall other Arguments and enducements to incline us rather for England, briefly mentioned. With an inference from the whole preceding di≈øcour≈øe, that the friend≈øhip of England is to be preferd before that of France.

9. That we are not yet come to that extremity, but we may ≈øtill remaine a Republick; in regard of our owne ≈øtrength, and our Neighbors Intre≈øt, Englands e≈øpecially; that they had better lo≈øe Scotland or Ireland, then let the French have the≈øe Provinces. This War a Game at Hazard. Being engaged will goe through, and Parliament probably a≈ø≈øi≈øt therein.
10. Compliance with England, the onely meanes of the Commonwealths continuation.

11. Conjectures of future affaires. The motions of the en≈øuing Summer likely to be quick and great. As to this Republick, probably England may get a bridle to curb us, France the ≈øadle to ride us, Colen a Supernumerary girth, Mun≈øter a bos off the crupper. Our condition deplored and con≈øolated. A nece≈ø≈øary caution for England, another for the Orange Family. The Authors feares of what will at la≈øt befall us. The Spani≈øh Netherlands a dying. The friend≈øhip of England and France ≈øick at heart, and cannot live long. That of Spaine and England ≈øound at heart, and will recover, &c.

12. France's Ambition. Growing greatnes. The cau≈øes thereof. We and England in the fault. The Common Intre≈øt of Europe to oppo≈øe France particularly declared of the Empire, Spaine, England, Denmarke, and this Republick and Hans Townes. Yea of Sweden, Savoy, and Switzerland. The ballance of Europe to be held even, and by whom.
13. The Conclu≈øion of the whole Di≈øcour≈øe.

div.head: To the Impartial Reader.
div.p: ALthough in ≈øo ≈ømall a Tractate, it may be thought needle≈øs to give an account of the occa≈øion thereof; yet I think my ≈øelf obliged for your further ≈øatisfaction, to do it briefly. The Author having been lately in Holland, found what the Zeelanders had done in the late Revolutions, mi≈øunder≈øtood by ≈øome, and variou≈øly cen≈øured by others; and therefore thought it worth his pains, fairly and mode≈øtly to vindicate the ≈øame. And the rather, becau≈øe he fore≈øees various pretexts will be deduced thence, and divers interpretations be made thereof, which the Author hopes by his declaring the true intent and meaning, to free it from. That ≈øo all tho≈øe, who≈øe Curio≈øity or Intere≈øt leads them to inquire, might be acquainted with the true Grounds and Rea≈øons thereof; and that neither the propen≈øity of ≈øome to the French, nor the prejudice and pa≈ø≈øion of others again≈øt the Engli≈øh, might make us run blindfold upon our ruine; but that we may di≈øcern our true Intere≈øt, and pur≈øue it as occa≈øion ≈øhall require. For as all affection to that which is not our real Intere≈øt, ≈øo all aver≈øation from that which is, is madne≈øs and folly; which clouds Rea≈øon, precipitates Coun≈øels, runs us upon extreams, and drives us into inevitable de≈øtruction, many times before we are aware.

I know ≈øome will be apt to ≈øay, What need of this now? The Storm is over, and the ≈øuppo≈øition of inability to defend our felves out of doors. If I thought ≈øo, I a≈ø≈øure you I ≈øhould neither trouble my ≈øelf, nor others any further. But whether it be my love to the Countrey, and de≈øire of the welfare thereof; or my jealou≈øie over the Factions of the Rulers, and tumultuou≈øne≈øs of the people therein; or my comparing and e≈øtimating our own ≈øtrength, fidelity, and courage with our Enemies; or my ob≈øerving, that our former Military Di≈øcipline (which made us renowned, and our Countrey accounted the School of War) is in a great mea≈øure, if not utterly decayed and lo≈øt; or my hearing how old Officers, and Forein Forces have been ≈ølighted; and ≈øuch preferred, as are unexperienced for conduct, and untried for courage; or the difference I have ob≈øerved in the valour of a poor and rich people; Poverty always ≈øtirring up and whetting Valour, out of hopes to better their condition; whereas riches makes men fearful of lo≈øing what they have, and ≈øo falling into a wor≈øe. As may be ob≈øerved not onely in different people, as between the Northern and Southern Nations, but al≈øo in the ≈øame, yea in our ≈øelves. For when poor in our Wars with Spain, De Mor. Gern. ¬ß. 29. we made good the old Character which Tacitus gives us, Omnium harum gentium virtute pr ‚Ä¢ ecip ‚Ä¢ i Batavi, &c. Of
all the German Nations, or People, the Batavians, were cheif for valour; but now that we are grown rich, we are affraid to adventure either our Per≈øons or E≈øtates, and readier to open our Gates, then ≈øhut them again≈øt our Enemies. Or, whether it be my Melancholly temper only; or my fears and cowardi≈øe, if you plea≈øe to call it ≈øo; or my fancy from my ob≈øervation, that the third War (as this is with England) hath ever proved fatal to the one ≈øide, as is apparent by many examples; or what ever other cau≈øe it is, I mu≈øt profe≈øs freely, that I am of another ≈øentiment, this War having ≈øo black a vi≈øage to mine appearance, that I fear we are rather in the mid≈øt of a Tempe≈øtuous Sea of Troubles, then di≈øcovering of Land, much le≈øs a ≈øafe Harbour of re≈øt.

I am not ignorant upon how many pins men hang their hopes. Some upon the advancement of his Highne≈øs the Prince of Orange, hope all will be redre≈øt and well at home; and that his relation to the Crown of England, and the Elector of Brandenburgh, will capacitate him to remedy all abroad. Others upon conjectures of his marrying with the Duke of Yorks Daughter, or ≈øome nearly related to the Crown of England or France; which hath been an u≈øual way I confe≈øs, e≈øpecially among ab≈øolute Princes, of accomodating differences. Some upon our ≈øufficient numbers of Men and Moneys to defend our ≈øelves. Other≈øome upon the A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Emperor, and the German Princes, Brandenburgh e≈øpecially. And others upon their opinion, that now the Pen≈øionary de Wit and his party are broken, ≈øo that England can confide more in our friend≈øhip, that the King will break with France, and afford his Nephew and the≈øe Netherlands a≈ø≈øi≈øtance; e≈øpecially becau≈øe they judge, that it is the Intere≈øt of England and Germany, as well as Spain, not to ≈øee us fall into the French hands, for fear they have only Polyphemus his courte≈øie, to be la≈øt devoured. But yet all the≈øe grouds, and divers others, which are variou≈øly di≈øcour≈øed of, prevail not ≈øo far with me, as that my hopes can ballance my fears.

For although I grant the ≈øtrength of the remaining Provinces to be con≈øiderable both by Sea and Land; and the greate≈øt foundation to build our hopes upon, next under God Almighties Protection; yet if we duly con≈øider the ≈øtate and condition we are in, there is not that ju≈øt ground of confidence, which may free us from fears; as many are apt to imagine. He is very ≈øhort ≈øighted that ob≈øerves not,
1. That there are two different parties among≈øt us, and that a Commonwealth, muchle≈øs then a Kingdom divided, cannot ≈øtand.
2. That we might do much more then we do, or (for any thing I yet ≈øee) will or ≈øhall do for our own defence.
3. That we are de≈øtitute of ≈øuccours from abroad for the pre≈øent, except from Spain; which we may happily pay dear enough for; if we ≈øhould be drawn into a League Offen≈øive and Defen≈øive with them in a long and tedious War. And
4. that we are full of tumults and di≈øtractions at home, which is to me a greater pre≈øage of approaching ruine, then all our Enemies weapons of War; and makes me fear that as tumults was the occa≈øion
of our ri≈øing, ≈øo they will be of our ruine.Hi≈øt. Gal. l. 2. And that Priols ob≈øervation of two only Nations that have ≈øtood firm by defection; the Helvetians at the ri≈øe, and the Hollanders at the fall of the Rhine; tho≈øe founding and defending their Liberty by the Mountains, their Poverty, and Equality; the≈øe by the Waters, their Riches, and the States with a Captain General; may ≈øhortly be contradicted in the latter, if we be not more unanimous, and perhaps ere long in the former al≈øo.

I grant likewi≈øe, That it is very con≈øiderable to have ≈øo wi≈øe a Conductor as the Prince of Orange is for his years, and one of ≈øuch near Relation to two ≈øuch great Potentates as his Uncles of England and Brandenburgh. But yet if we rightly con≈øider, we cannot but conclude.
1. That it mu≈øt be Power, as well as Policy, that can relieve us; and that in the Affairs of the World, Intere≈øt is preferred above all Relations; the whole World turning upon the Hinge of Self-intere≈øt; and all Princes, States, Families, and Per≈øons eagerly pur≈øuing that which they apprehend their Intere≈øt, although often mi≈øtaking it, and oftner the means to obtain it; no wonder if they mi≈øs thereof.
2. And that his Civil Dignities come rather to him by Popular Tumults, than Regular Proceedings: Which is found an ea≈øie way to ri≈øe by, but a hard way to ≈øtand by, yea, Morally impo≈ø≈øible, if not backed by power. For as it is with ≈øick Per≈øons, ≈øo with ≈øick States, if all things be not quickly redre≈ø≈øed that is grievous to them, they pre≈øently cry, Turn me again; and think they have power to undo, that which they them≈øelves have formerly done. It being a true Character which Livy gives the Common People, Lib. 24. Plebs aut humiliter ≈øervit, aut ≈øuperb√® dominatur.
3. And that though the de Wits be dead, their party lives; and if things ≈øucceed not well under his Highne≈øs, will have no ≈ømall advantage, not only from the horrid murder of tho≈øe two Pillars of their party; but from the declining of Affairs, to cry him down with the people, and make him an In≈øignificant Cypher of State.
4. And la≈øtly, There are ≈øo many Papi≈øts, and other Sects of Religion and Malecontents, who watch for opportunities to Flieblow the Common People, and ≈øet them upon Sedition; that I much que≈øtion, whether that fre≈øh gale of Affection to the Prince, which hath blown ≈øo briskly through all the≈øe remaining Provinces, will la≈øt long. For if they ≈øee that his Highne≈øs cannot make Peace, as they expected; and they feel more mi≈øerable effects of a ≈øtubborn and cruel War, and be forced to greater Taxes (the Common People being always covetous, what ever the cau≈øe or nece≈ø≈øity be) and find their Trade ≈øtill ob≈øtructed, and Land drowned, to the impoveri≈øhing both of Cities and Countrey; I fear we ≈øhall find the People ≈øo re≈øtle≈øs and unquiet, that they will neither know what to do them≈øelves, nor be willing to be guided by their Governors that do; but when Extremities pre≈øs upon us, bring all into Confu≈øion, and con≈øequently Ruine.

For be≈øides the Jealou≈øies which many have of his Highne≈øs, which Bentivoglio long ≈øince fore≈øaw and foretold, That the≈øe Jealou≈øies betwixt the State, and their Stadtholder, would become the cau≈øe of our Ruine; the needy
multitude, (which are alwaies enemies to good order and Government) when di≈øtre≈ø≈øed; will ≈øeek occa≈øion to prey upon the richer, whom they con≈øtantly envie. And the midle ≈øort, which are the true Ba≈øis of a State, who≈øe principal aime is Liberty and Plenty, when they ≈øee the≈øe indangered; grow jealous of their Governours (upon whom all misfortunes are con≈øtantly laid) and ≈øeeke to pull them downe and ≈øet up them≈øeves one after another, to the ruine of all. For the pompe of Government ≈øo da≈øles the eyes of tho≈øe that know not the Weight of it, that when there is any ≈øeeming acce≈øs thereto, all are apt to contend for it, and every one to thinke him≈øelf as capable as his neighbor, and vy with one another without end: till they that were formerly good pa≈ø≈øengers, now turning Pilots in a Storm; through their continuall contentions and unskilfulne≈øs, ≈øhipwrack the Common-wealth, whil≈øt they ≈øincerely de≈øire and endeavour to ≈øave it. I ≈øhall therefore conclude, that although we have a good Head, yet except the members be at unity, and unanimou≈øly re≈øolved to give a≈ø≈øi≈øtance to their Head and Governours; it is in vaine to thinke, we can be ≈øecured from ≈øuch potent enemies, (except any be ≈øo mad as to expect miracles) or that the Princes name or waying of his Flag upon our Towers can defend us.

For his marrying his Highne≈øs the Duke of Yorks Daughter, we may ≈øpeak of it here, and tho≈øe in England of the King of Sweden, and both be mi≈øtaken. I can ≈øee little certainty thereof, and therefore can ≈øay le≈øs therein; but this I can ≈øay, that if a Relation would effect our de≈øires, there is that which is very near already; yea which many perhaps will thinke too neer, if it conduce no more to the procuring our Peace.

For our a≈ø≈øi≈øtance from the Emperor and Germain Princes, which is ≈øo much talkt of, the Brandenburgs e≈øpecially; if I were a≈ø≈øured they de≈øigned to ≈øerve us, and not them≈øelves of us; I ≈øhould have more hopes then I have. I know the Germains are a great and warlike Nation, and that none almo≈øt have warred with them, that have not repented it. And when we ≈øee them warr with France, though they directly a≈ø≈øi≈øt us not further, ≈øuch a diver≈øion to our enemie will be a con≈øiderable advantage to us. But at pre≈øent, we ≈øee no more of their intentions, than to defend them≈øelves. The Emperor is not onely continually kept waking by the Turk; but at pre≈øent diverted al≈øo by the di≈øtractions of Hungary. And the fears of Poland, will nece≈ø≈øitate Brandenburg to have an eye to Pru≈ø≈øia. The Princes of the Empire are many, and divided, (≈øeveral of them declaring for France, others wavering and waiting opportunity to clo≈øe with the prevailing ≈øide) which makes their Coun≈øels ≈ølow, and more ≈øubject to be di≈øcovered, the rai≈øing men and bringing them together more difficult, the commanding of them more lyable to di≈øcord (which hath often proved fatal in their Armies) and the providing for them very uncertaine. And I might ad hereunto (for it is well knowne) that ≈øome of the Germain Princes have ≈øo run out their revenues; that though they have men far more then their proportion, yet have not money to pay the half of their rate. So that it is well, if
what was ≈øaid of old of the Britains, prove not true of the Germans, Tacitus in vita Agricolae. Dum ≈øinguli pugnant, omnes vincuntur.

As for the Intere≈øt of England, which we think ≈øhould incline them to hinder rather than further Frances growing greatne≈øs, and con≈øequently to Peace with us: I ≈øhall only ≈øay this, That as we allow all men liberty to judge of their own Intere≈øts, ≈øo mu≈øt we much more to Kings and Rulers. And it is but rea≈øonable to think, that they under≈øtand their own Intere≈øt better then we, that are ≈øtrangers to their de≈øigns; except we think of our ≈øelves as the Per≈øians, who ≈øay that they have two eyes, and others but one. I may think, that the ≈øame Rea≈øon of State ≈øhould prevail now, that did formerly with the Engli≈øh, in the fir≈øt War, To humble us, but not ruine us; and ≈øhall make it apparent, that they cannot rationally have a thought of our ruine, without thinking to follow after, yet circum≈øtances are ≈øo different, and the pa≈ø≈øions of men ≈øo various, that I am not certain to what extent and degree of Humiliation they mea≈øure their Intere≈øt, or how far England is ingaged with France for effecting of this. We may think, and the Engli≈øh Nation may be jealous (as I know they are) that France will couzen them at la≈øt, and ≈øerve them now as Comines tells us they have formerly,l. 3. c. 8. & l. 4. c. 9. Bodin de Rep. l. 5. c. 1.
When u≈øually they beat the French in their Wars; but then what they had got by their Swords, they lo≈øt by their Treaties, (even as Bodin tells us the French were ≈øerv'd by the Spaniards;) but if they will adventure that, who can hinder them?

Should I ≈øpeak my private apprehen≈øion, 'tis briefly this, England hath been long jealous of the growing greatne≈øs of this State by Sea, and find it an error of Policy in former Governors, to ≈øuffer us to arrive at this height of conte≈øting with them. From whence they have met with ≈øeveral inconveniences in regard of Trade, and al≈øo been put to va≈øt expences to maintain con≈øtantly a Fleet to cope with us. The≈øe things they would willingly ea≈øe them≈øelves of, which they know cannot be done, but by the Sword. The fir≈øt War which was occa≈øionally begun, was no time to effect their de≈øigns, in regard the Kingdom was harra≈øt and exhau≈øted by a long Civil War, and Oliver the Protectors cheif de≈øign was to ≈øettle him≈øelf, and therefore made Peace. The ≈øecond War advantaged them nothing; for the French countenancing us (though ≈øecretly in League with them before the War was ended) they were not able to effect what they de≈øigned, having lo≈øt their opportunity which they had after the fir≈øt battel in their hands: That being often verified of the Engli≈øh, which was ≈øaid of Hannibal, (by whom matters not, for the Learned Hi≈øtorians Livie and Plutarch differ therein,) Vincere ≈øcis Hannibal; victoria uti ne≈øcis. A Peace is concluded at Breda, but the War had a ≈øting in the tale of it, the work at Chattam, Ma ‚Ä¢ et alta mente repo≈øtum, and makes them more eagerly wait for an opportunity, both to revenge them≈øelves, and pur≈øue their former de≈øigns. And now France taking occa≈øion to quarrel with us, they take the opportunity to oppre≈øs us, and bring us under; that they may free them≈øelves from tho≈øe pre≈øent inconveniences in Trade and Expences, and will ≈øee how they can make it with France
for the future. They know well, that if we be broken, there is no Nation el≈øe is able to match them at Sea, and being in an Iland, fear not inva≈øion by Land Forces. I might parallel this with the Peloponne≈øian War, the cau≈øe whereof was the Athenians growing greatne≈øs, and particularly in Power at Sea;Lib. 1. upon whom therefore, the Lacedemonians made War, as Thucydides tells us, who hath accurately writ the Hi≈øtory thereof. div.head: Sect. 1. The ri≈øe and ≈øtate of the Que≈øtion, viz. Whether upon ≈øuppo≈øal of inability to defend our ≈øelves, it is our Intere≈øt to be under England or France, and the Zeelanders choice of the former.
div.p: HE is a Stranger to us and our Affairs, who knows not; that the late Revolutions among us, and particularly at ∆≤trechts betaking them≈øelves to the French for protection, were attended both with great con≈øternation, and various deliberations, as is u≈øual in ≈øuch di≈øa≈øters. When therefore mi≈øery and de≈øtruction was approaching as a violent torrent, that bears down all before it; Self-pre≈øervation being the Fundamental Law of Nature; every Province, City, and almo≈øt Village, began to con≈øider, what they ≈øhould do to pre≈øerve them≈øelves, from being drowned in the overflowing deluge.

Some were of opinion, that the remaining Provinces were of ≈øufficient ≈øtrength to defend them≈øelves, and therefore lookt no further. Others were of a contrary judgment; and therefore thought it better, upon rea≈øonable terms, to put our ≈øelves under a Forein Power, as ∆≤trecht had done, then to be conquered by the Sword. And herein al≈øo mens judgments were divided, ≈øome thinking it better to be under the French, others to be under the Engli≈øh. Tho≈øe of Holland (as was commonly reported) were more inclinable to the former, in regard of their near approach to them in ∆≤trecht; and e≈øpecially out of an opinion which many have entertained, That the Intere≈øt of Holland, being principally that of Trade by Sea, was more competible with that of France then England, In≈øomuch, that many believe, if the advice of Mon≈øieur Pompone of the Kings ≈øending Charte Blanche had been followed; the Cities of Holland had at that time ≈øeveral of them imitated the example of ∆≤trecht; tho≈øe of Zealand were generally inclined to the Engli≈øh. But as opinions are u≈øually both bred and brought up by Pa≈ø≈øions; ≈øo here it was manife≈øt, That the exce≈ø≈øive hopes of the former, made them for ab≈øolute defence; and the exce≈ø≈øive fears of the latter, for ab≈øolute re≈øignation. In ≈øuch ca≈øes there are two ways have always been found ≈øafe≈øt and be≈øt for accommodation, viz. A due examination of the Grounds of tho≈øe Pa≈ø≈øions, and a ju≈øt temperament or comprehen≈øion of the diver≈øity of Opinions: Which here ≈øo happily fell out, that it was re≈øolved upon and declared by many in Zeeland, fir≈øt, That they would u≈øe their be≈øt endeavors to defend them≈øelves; and ≈øecondly, if they found them≈øelves unable, they Would then re≈øign to the Engli≈øh. Hereby ≈øhewing, that they neither did through vain fears, wholly de≈øpond of their own ≈øtrength; nor through flattering hopes were wholly fearle≈øs of their Enemies. They would try and u≈øe the be≈øt means they could, to ≈øtand of them≈øelves according to their hopes; and yet al≈øo provide again≈øt the wor≈øt of their fears, which was their fall by ab≈øolute conque≈øt.

For the manner of doing this, I ≈øhall neither accu≈øe, nor defend it; though the Magi≈øtrate led not the Van of Con≈øent, according to his place and dignity,Plut. l. de fort. yet he followed clo≈øe in the Rear. And though it was done ha≈øtily, yet why may not a ha≈øty Pen, ≈øometimes be as happy as Apelles his Pencil, which in Pa≈ø≈øion being thrown on the Picture, better portrayed the Hor≈øes foaming, then all his premeditated Coun≈øel and Art.

It is enough to me, and to my purpo≈øe, that what was done is agreeable to the true Intere≈øt of the Countrey; which I hope to make apparent in the following Di≈øcour≈øe. But before I do that, give me leave to premi≈øe a few things, which tend to the clearing of the Matters in que≈øtion.

list.item: 1. That we only ≈øuppo≈øe this inability for the pre≈øent, to ≈øatisfie the curio≈øity of the World, which never think their teli≈øcope long enough, to ≈øee to the utmo≈øt end of Intere≈øt. div.head: Sect. 2. Arguments to prove the Hypothe≈øis, the fir≈øt whereof is from our Religious Concernments; wherein is ≈øhewn how great a ≈øupport Religion is to a State, and how greatly it concern us to ≈øecure our Religion.
div.p: HAving now truly related Matter of Fact, and clearly ≈øtated the Que≈øtion, I ≈øhall proceed to prove the ≈øame, viz. That in ca≈øe of inability to defend our ≈øelves, it is our Intere≈øt to be under the Engli≈øh rather than the French.

Fir≈øt in regard of Religion. Which as it is of cheife≈øt concernment, ≈øo de≈øerves to have the precedence of all other con≈øiderations. It is ≈øo well known how the Heathens of old, and Turks of later times have valued their ≈øeveral fal≈øe Religions; how their fir≈øt Founders, Legi≈ølators, and Magi≈øtrates have made Religion, both the Ba≈øis upon which they founded their Kingdoms and Commonwealths, and the cheif Pillars to ≈øupport them; and how zealous the common people have been for their Super≈øtitions: That I cannot but wonder that Chri≈øtians ≈øhould be ≈øuch Gallices for the true Religion and Go≈øpel of Chri≈øt, and fear that Turks and Heathens will ri≈øe up in judgment again≈øt us, and condemn us for our indifferency herein. If any be of another judgement,Serres. in Lewis 11. Bu≈ø≈øieres. Hi≈øt. Fra. l. 13. ¬ß. 9. & 24. Comin. l. 6, c. 7. & 12. Anti-Machiavel, &c. and prefer the Rea≈øon of State above Religion (although in this ca≈øe they are conjoyned, as I ≈øhal ≈øhew hereafter) I wi≈øh ≈øuch would oberve from Lewis the 11, who fir≈øt opened the pack of fraudulent polices to the Princes of Europe; what di≈ømall ends have befallen him, and the Athei≈øtical Polititians ≈øince, tho≈øe of Italy e≈øpecially; and what di≈øappoyntments their de≈øigns have met withall, and ≈øee if they have any rea≈øon to treade in their ≈øteps. Belial before Chri≈øt: If ≈øo, we are fitter to be our enemies a≈ø≈øes, to be laden with their trumperies, and la≈øht at their plea≈øure, than to be dealt withall by arguments to convince our Con≈øciences.

If we duly con≈øider that true Religion is
1. The Fountaine of all true Piety and Vertue here, and of eternall Felicity hereafter.

4. That which onely can a≈ø≈øure a people of Gods favour and being propitious to them; and the contempt thereof on the contrary, of his di≈øplea≈øure and malediction; We mu≈øt needs conclude, that the Magi≈øtrate in the fir≈øt place as Gods Vice-gerent in Governement, and all others in their ≈øeverall Stations, ought to endeavour above all things by all lawfull means to pre≈øerve, defend, and ≈øecure the ≈øame; as they tender the honour of God, the welfare of his Church, the pro≈øperity of the Commonwealth, and their own and Po≈øterities temporall and eternall happines. div.head: Sect. 3. The plea of France's granting us the liberty of our Religion con≈øidered.

Now ≈øuppo≈øe we have Governors that mea≈øures con≈øciences by ells rather than inches; who matters no more engagements di≈øpen≈øed with by his Holines, than we doe our Almanacks out of date. 4. The Papi≈øts mu≈øt have publique places for their Wor≈øhip, not only in all Cities but Villages, as we may ≈øee in the Articles propounded by the French. Now there being by far too few Churches or places for publique Wor≈øhip, in mo≈øt of our populous and enlarged Cities allready; it will not be po≈ø≈øible for a great part of our Religion, to enjoy the publique Ordinances of God; but many will run into profane cour≈øes, mo≈øt grow ignorant and careles what Religion they are of, and their po≈øterity ab≈øolute Papi≈øts. By which meanes the number of the Reformed decrea≈øing, and Papi≈øts increa≈øing; where at fir≈øt there was but onely one Church for popery; they ≈øhall then take more, and ≈øo continue to inlarge them≈øelves and ≈øtraten us. Nor let any judge the≈øe, as onely jealou≈øies and feares. For if they begin allready to incroach (as it is credibly reported from ≈øeverall places they command) and breake Articles heerein, when not onely the commands of ≈øuperiors, but common policy requires a mo≈øt religious ob≈øervance thereof; what ≈øhall we thinke they will doe hereafter? If they will not now out of hopes to win tho≈øe to them, which yet ≈øtand out: much les will they, when there is no more hope of gaining thereby.

5. When popery is the Religion of our Governors, who have the di≈øpo≈øall of preferments and profits, to allure men to their Religion: We ≈øhall find by wofull experience, what by education, conver≈øe, marriages, dignities and other worthy advantages; many of the ignoranter and loo≈øer ≈øort of Prote≈øtants, will change their profe≈ø≈øion (I ≈øay not Religion for that ≈øuch never had) and turne Papi≈øts. Who is ≈øuch a ≈øtranger in the world as knowes not, that by ≈øuch artifices they have more weakened the Prote≈øtants
in France, than by all their wars and conte≈øts with them. In ≈øo much that of late yeares, ≈øome wi≈øe men of the Reformed Religion there, have bene ≈øo fear full of its being utterly ≈øupplanted; that they have required their children by their la≈øt will and Te≈øtament, to leave that Kingdome, and ≈øetle them≈øelves in the≈øe Countries.

6. Let the be≈øt he ≈øuppo≈øed that any rationall man can imagine, yet will it be bad enough. For if the Papi≈øts have the Civill power to back them, allthough the wi≈øer and better ≈øort, it is not to be doubted will be civill; yet the the ruder ≈øort will be intollerably in≈øolent. And this begins to appear in ≈øome places allready, where the Popi≈øh Inhabitants are more in≈øufferably in≈øulting, ≈øpightfull, and injurious than the French them≈øelves. And if they doe this ≈øo early while things are doubifull, and the i≈ø≈øue of the War dubious; what may we expect when they are in their high Meridian of ≈øucces and glory?

7. And la≈øtly, if any one thinkes that the≈øe are onely needles feares and groundles ≈øurmi≈øes, I ≈øhall de≈øire them to peru≈øe the French Emba≈ø≈øadors Speech to the Emperors Council,Gremonville. where he will find this Argument of Religion in≈øi≈øted on to divert the Emperor from our a≈ø≈øi≈øtance (which is well retorted by the ingenious An≈øwerer thereof.) And inform them≈øelves how fa≈øt the Je≈øuits and other Zealots for the Romi≈øh Religion, fall off from the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria and Spaint to France; in regard of their inability to carry on their de≈øigns of the Univer≈øall Popi≈øh Monarchy, and the hopes they have of France's potency to effect it. And then let them judge, if there be not ≈øufficient ground, for all that I have ≈øaid, and much more that might be ≈øaid upon this Subject.

div.head: Sect. 4: Objections from the danger of lo≈øing our Religion under England; from the Kings being a Papi≈øt, de≈øigning to ≈øet up Popery; the increa≈øe, countenance, and tolleration of Papi≈øts, as al≈øo from his joyning with France again≈øt us, and Church Governement by Bi≈øhops, all an≈øwered.
div.p: But now on the other hand it is by ≈øome objected again≈øt the Engli≈øh.
1. That the King is a Papi≈øt in heart, and de≈øignes to ≈øet up the Popi≈øh Religion.

Fir≈øt what the King is in his heart, and what he de≈øignes, is onely knowne to God Almighty, who is the ≈øearcher of hearts. That he is a profe≈øt prote≈øtant, is well knowne. And allthough I will not ≈øweare for him nor any man alive, that he will not change his Religion; yet to me it ≈øeems very improbable, upon the following grounds.

1. He that would not in his minority, when under his Mothers education in France, K. Charles I. Letters. but followed his Fathers in≈øtructions, of being obedient to her in all things, excepting the matter of her Religion; I cannot thinke will now in his maturity.

2. His with≈øtanding ≈øo many temptations wherewith he was environed ≈øo long a time together, during tho≈øe many years of his exile; wherein neither the friend≈øhip of Papi≈øts, nor unkindne≈øs and hard mea≈øure he met withal from Prote≈øtants could move him;Militiere's Victory of the Truth, and Bp. Bramhalls An≈øwer. makes me think him much more immovable, now he is free from tho≈øe. Who that knows tho≈øe times, knows not what de≈øigns the Papi≈øts had upon him? What Per≈øwa≈øions and Arguments they u≈øed both by word and writing? What Promi≈øes they made him of a≈ø≈øi≈øtance to recover his Kingdoms? What Arguments of Intere≈øt they pre≈øt him with, which are u≈øually more prevalent with Princes, than the intrin≈øick Arguments of Religion? And if he ≈øtood un≈øhaken in all tho≈øe boy≈øterous bla≈øts, ≈øhall we thinke he will fall in a calme?

3. His re≈øcuing his younge≈øt Brother the Duke of Gloce≈øter out of his Mothers hands, when her de≈øignes appeared for perverting him in his Religion; is an evident proofe of the realty of his Profe≈ø≈øion. If any one ≈øay it was his Intere≈øt for regaining his Kingdoms. I ≈øay.

4. And is it not his Intere≈øt al≈øo for keeping them? Did he gaine them ≈øo quickly, or are his three Kingdoms ≈øo little worth, that he ≈øhould ea≈øily hazard them? Kings are wi≈øer then to venture their Crownes upon every idle Prie≈øts pratles. If there were any ≈øtronger Arguments now then formerly, either for the Popi≈øh Religion, or from his Intere≈øt; we had ≈øome rea≈øon to be jealous that he might change.
But 5. It is apparently again≈øt his Intere≈øt, not onely in regard of the danger he might incur of lo≈øing his Crownes, but the great lo≈øs which would inevitably accrew to him by this change.

The danger we cannot imagine to be ≈ømall, if we rightly con≈øider tho≈øe Kingdoms. I have had an accompt (having been a little curious in tho≈øe enquiries) of 1100000 of his Subjects, that by Intere≈øt and Inclination were carried counter to the Court. Under the≈øe five Heads.
1. The Purcha≈øers of Crowne and Church Lands that are now re≈øtored, and they outed.
2. Soldiers and Seamen, that had fought again≈øt him by Sea and Land.
3. Magi≈øtrates and Mini≈øters, that were removed and turned out of their places.
4. Commonwealths Men that were Anti-monarchicall in their judgments.
5. Fanaticks properly ≈øo called, as Anabapti≈øts, Fifth Monarchy Men, Quakers, &c. And though I could perhaps give as good a gue≈øs as another, at the re≈øt of the Sub≈øtantiall Prote≈øtants that are of the Epi≈øcopall per≈øwa≈øion, yet that needs not now. The≈øe you mu≈øt thinke, however divided in their Intere≈øts, Judgments, and Affections; and many of them, no doubt very Loyal to his Maje≈øty; yet without all doubt would joyne again≈øt Popery, and never willingly ≈øubmit them≈øelves to that yoke of bondage. Nay, ≈øome perhaps would be glad of ≈øuch an Argument, and Plea to the people, and the Demagogues gaine thereby no ≈ømall number of Pro≈øelytes to their Party, if his Maje≈øty was once a declared Papi≈øt.

And as his danger, you ≈øee is great, ≈øo his lo≈øs I am ≈øure could not be
≈ømall.
1. Of his Honour, not onely in changing that Religion he hath now ≈øo long profe≈øt, and blurring the faire copy which his Father hath ≈øet him; but in admitting the Popes Supremacy: which hath beene ≈øo Injurious to the dignities of Emperors, Kings, and Princes; that their complaints how they have beene plagued by the Popes are infinite.
2. Of his profit and revenues,Vid. Bodin de Rep. l. 1: c. 9. in regard that the Peter-pence or Tenths of Livings, and other Contributions paid formerly to the Pope, are by Law annexed to the Crowne, and paid accordingly, to the King.
3. Of his Subjects affections, wherein his ≈øafety e≈øpecially con≈øi≈øts. For a Prince that hath the hearts of his people, hath their pur≈øes and per≈øons at his ≈øervice; and raignes more happily by their love, then all his owne power though never ≈øo great. If we therefore con≈øider his education in, and his long profe≈ø≈øion of the prote≈øtant Religion, his honour and intre≈øt ingaging him to per≈øevere therein: I ≈øhould thinke no man need feare his changing it for the Popi≈øh, the fopperies whereof he hath ≈øo fully both ≈øeen and knowne.

I might ad to the≈øe, that which further ≈øatisfies me, that having been at Bruxels, Colen, and mo≈øt of tho≈øe places, where his Maje≈øty during his exile did re≈øide; I can ≈øay bona fide that in all the variety of companies and conver≈øe I was ever in, I never heard any probable grounds, from any one intelligent per≈øon, that toucht, much les ≈øtain'd his Maje≈øties reputation in this particular. But I will not impo≈øe this upon others, though it moves me to ≈øay the more, becau≈øe I am not willing to annex my name to what I have written. Not that I am a≈øhamed to owne what I conceive to be the reall truth, which I have publi≈øhed in this treati≈øe to the world, and can make good much more largely: but becau≈øe I know who I am, and that my name can ad no e≈øtimation to this politicall di≈øcour≈øe; but rather perhaps prejudice ≈øome who knowes me not, and are u≈øed to judge of writings by their authors; whereas tho≈øe that will impartially ≈øearch after truth, mu≈øt have regard to things, not per≈øons and to what is written, and not the writers thereof.
As for his ≈øetting up popery, I neither thinke that he will, for the foregoing rea≈øons; nor if he would, that he can, for the≈øe following e≈øpecially.

list.item: 1. The Prote≈øtant Religion is ≈øetled in all his Kingdomes by their fundamentall lawes, which the King cannot repeale. It is true he hath the executive power of the lawes, and ≈øo can ≈øu≈øpend the execution of penalties; but cannot re≈øcind any one law, much le≈ø≈øe make new ones, without the con≈øent of Parliament in his re≈øpective Kingdomes. And ab≈øolute Soveraingty is not there in u≈øe. For power paramount to all lawes, carries too great a top-≈øaile for an Engli≈øh bottom; wherein the Subjects liberties are ≈øhipt, as well as Coe≈øar and his fortunes.

2. The lands and revenues formerly ≈øupporting the Romi≈øh Religion, which are many and great, are in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the nobility and gentry for the mo≈øt part; and have beene bought by them of the Crowne at the
di≈ø≈øolution of Abbies, Mona≈øteries, &c. And the purcha≈øes confirmed by law. And can we thinke that they will be ever induced to part with them againe? or enact any ≈øuch lawes as ≈øhall tend to their owne ruine, and the utter undoing of their families? If there was ≈øo much danger and difficulty to wre≈øt them out of the hands of the poore Votaries, (as the Hi≈øtories of tho≈øe times tell us) What will there be to recover them from the powerfull Nobility and Gentry? who legally po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing them will doubtle≈øs defend them, ≈øo that none ≈øhall deprive them thereof, that have not better courage and ≈øharper Swords then they.

3. The great di≈øparity in the number of Prote≈øtants and Papi≈øts. There being not one family of a hundred in England and Scotland Popi≈øh, and in many and great Pari≈øhes not a Papi≈øt. Now what greater madne≈øs can we imagine, than that his Maje≈øty ≈øhould adventure to rely upon the Papi≈øts alone, again≈øt all the Prote≈øtants of the three Nations. Though their numbers are greater then formerly, yet are they comparatively ≈ømall (as we have ≈øaid) to tho≈øe that profes the Reformed Religion. So that it can never enter into my braine, that ≈øuch folly ≈øhould enter into any Princes bre≈øt, much les one who hath ≈øuffered ≈øo much, by the former divi≈øions of his Kingdoms.

4. The va≈øt difference between a people enlightned by the Go≈øpel, and well grounded in their Religion, and an ignorant and unprincipled people. For the generality of the common people brought up in ignorance, (as they u≈øually are under Popery) are more ≈øubject to receive impre≈ø≈øions from their Teachers, and ≈øo by degrees change their Profe≈ø≈øion. Whereas tho≈øe who are a≈ø≈øured from the Word of God, that they are in the right; will by no means be induced to the ≈øame. And u≈øually the more force is u≈øed, the more ob≈øtinate they are. For a ≈øetled Con≈øcience de≈øpi≈øes dainger, and defies all the terrors and torments, that their cruelle≈øt adver≈øaries can invent. If in le≈ø≈øer differences of Church-government, the King hath found it ≈øo difficult, that after all the coercive Lawes, and other meanes he hath u≈øed, he tells the world, 'tis evident by the ≈øad experience of twelve yeares, that there is very little fruit of all tho≈øe forceable cour≈øes; Declar. March 15. 1672. what ≈øhall we think he is likely to gain in the greater and e≈ø≈øential differences of Religion ≈øhould he attempt any change therein? Surely not much from the Pious and ≈øober party of Prote≈øtants; for I neither matter nor mention the ruder ≈øort, and ignorant rable. Nay univer≈øall experience hath taught the World, that where any kind of Religion is powerfull, all force again≈øt it is weake and contemptible: and much more again≈øt the true Reformed Religion; as that wi≈øe and excellent Hi≈øtorian Thuanus ≈øhewes in the Preface to his Hi≈øtory,The other two are Calv. to his In≈øtit. & Cau≈øa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
to Polybius. which is one of tho≈øe three admirable Dedications, to the Crown of France, that are worthy to be read by all the Kings and Princes of Europe.

div.p:
I might add to the≈øe, the genious of the Engli≈øh Nation, which I know to be zealous in what way of Religion ≈øoever they take, as hath been ob≈øerved by ≈øeverall Authors. In times of Popery ≈øo addicted thereto, that they had
given mo≈øt of their means to the Church,Anno 7 Edv. 1.18 Edv. 3.15 Rich. 2. if the Statute of Mortmaine had not prohibited them. In the times of Libertini≈øme when a Republick, the Fanaticks were ≈øo intoxicated, that it was not enough for them to pu≈øh down the Pope, but they would break off all Government, for being his hornes,Polydor. Virgil. l. 17. and make every thing Antichri≈øtian that was not to their humor. When the King return'd and Epi≈øcopacy with him, that Party would not abate the three controverted Ceremonies (as a wi≈øe and moderate Bi≈øhop both foretold and lamented) for the univer≈øal Peace of the three Kingdoms.Surplice, Cros, and kneeling at St. Brownrig. Nay the very common rable would overflow both in drinke and devotion; kneel at a pillar, and reele at a Po≈øt. Though I know there are as pious, ≈øober, and ≈øerious Chri≈øtians of ≈øeverall per≈øwa≈øions (Epi≈øcopall Presbyterial and Independants) as any are in the Chri≈øtian Worid: but I ≈øay this to ≈øhew, that what way ≈øoever they take, they are not ea≈øily diverted.

But as groundle≈øs jealou≈øie, is both uncharitablene≈øs and folly; ≈øo where there is ju≈øt ground; not to be jealous is ≈øtupidity. It may therefore not be ami≈øs for our further ≈øatisfaction, to enquire into the≈øe Objectors grounds. And they are the≈øe,
1. The increa≈øe of Papi≈øts, at Court e≈øpecially.
2. The Kings countenancing and intru≈øting them with power.
3. His tollerating their Religion.
4. Joyning with France again≈øt us.

For the 1 and 2d I can ≈øay little of my own knowledge, it being many yeares ≈øince I ≈øaw either England or France. But I ≈øhall take reports u ‚Ä¢ on the publique faith of England and Holland for this once, though it be none of the be≈øt ≈øecurity. 1. Therefore that Papi≈øts increa≈øe, through the Queens Court, the extraordinary corre≈øpondence with France, the di≈ø≈øentions of the Prote≈øtants, the Athei≈øme and irreligion of the Age, and other wayes and meanes which might be mentioned, is not to be wondred at; but rather that there are no more. Allthough I am well a≈ø≈øured, that their number is comparatively ≈ømall, and their Intre≈øt in England and Scotland incon≈øiderable to effect any change. And were they more, this will not infer the King is one.

2. And much les his countenancing and intru≈øting them. For who ever concluded that the French Kings for their kindnes to Prote≈øtants, (who have ≈øerved them mo≈øt faithfully heretofore in their wars) were Prote≈øtants? Or the States Papi≈øts, for employing the French and others in their Armies? A Papi≈øt may be a loyall ≈øubject, a wi≈øe State≈øman, a fit Emba≈ø≈øador, a good Soldjer, and merit his Princes favor, though of a different Religion.

3. Nor will the Kings indulgence of liberty to tho≈øe of that Religion conclude more again≈øt our a≈ø≈øertion, then for the States of Hollands being of all the Religions they tollerate, or for Am≈øterdam's being Jewes. There may be rea≈øons of State, ≈øometimes to connive, and ≈øometimes to tollerate that, which we neither approve, nor would willingly allow; even as Mo≈øes did divorce to the Jewes. Or there may be Articles, promi≈øes and other engagements upon us, whereby we are forced to do that, which we would not if free: as Jo≈øhua to the Gibeonites; and our Ance≈øtors
to Papi≈øts, Anabapti≈øts, &c. who a≈ø≈øi≈øted them in the defence of the Countrey again≈øt Spaine.

There are two things doe wonders in the world, and are the ordinary pretexts and be≈øt apologies for the greate≈øt ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ bitances, viz:v. grot. An Jure bel. & pac. l. 1. c. 4. ¬ß. 7. l. 2. c. 2. ¬ß 6.
danger and nece≈ø≈øity. And yet where the≈øe are reall and not feigned, they are con≈øidered both by God and good men. Nature dictates, that we ≈øhould hazard the hand rather then the head, and lo≈øe a part, rather then venture the whole. I have for above 20 years ob≈øerved, both where I have lived, and where I have travelled; that Moderation is rather a ≈øpeculative notion, than matter of practi≈øe: like a vertuous and beautifull poor Lady, that all will commend, but none will marry. Parties that are under, call for it eagerly; but when they are upmo≈øt, neglect it ≈øhamefully. Seeing then the pa≈ø≈øions of men, and iniquities of the age are ≈øo great, that I ex≈øpect nothing in Religion, but either an inqui≈øition or tolleration; I am more for the latter, and would rather re≈øide at Am≈øterdam or Con≈øtantinople then at Rome or Madrid.

But to come clo≈øer to the particular ca≈øe. If his Maje≈øty therefore had no obligation upon him to do this, or were it a liberty to Papi≈øts only, or a liberty for their wor≈øhip in publick; I ≈øhould grant the objection was very weighty; but it is the quite contrary. For he tells the world he was obliged in point of gratitude to the Papi≈øts for their ≈øervice to his Father; and to the Presbyterians (who had been ≈øo in≈øtrumentall in his re≈øtoration) in point of promi≈øe all≈øo, ≈øeverall wayes made to them both before and after his returne to his Crowne; ≈øeverall times declaring that he would grant indulgence to them and others of tender con≈øciences And we know that if his Maje≈øty had followed his own inclinations, they had been better performed. And now that he gives a conce≈ø≈øion of liberty, it is neither ≈øoly nor principally to tho≈øe of the Romi≈øh Religion, but to all others as well as they, and that with this manife≈øt difference, that it is to the Prote≈øtants publiquely, and to Papi≈øts in their private hou≈øes onely, and this revocable at plea≈øure.Declar. March 15. 1672. All though ≈øome wi≈øe men are of opinion, that the King and Rulers will not onely find ≈øuch ea≈øe and ≈øafety therein; but ≈øuch eminent advantages many wayes, and the people generally ≈øuch content, that it will ≈øcarce be revoked.

4. His joyning with France again≈øt us, is matter of Intre≈øt, and not Religion. And if we judge impartially, will no more conclude him a Papi≈øt, then the Emperor and King of Spaine Prote≈øtants becau≈øe they joyne with us. Herein let us eye and owne the Providence of God, who changes times and ≈øea≈øons and makes friends become enimies, and enim ‚Ä¢ es Friends. Would not this have been thought incredible to our Ance≈øtors, that France and England who rai≈øed us, ≈øhould endeavour our ruine? And that Spaine and Au≈øtria who ≈øought our de≈øtruction, ≈øhould ever ≈øeek our pre≈øervation? And all this out of Intre≈øt, (as I ≈øhall ≈øhew hereafter) tho≈øe formerly to ballance Spaine's, and the≈øe now France's greatnes; and neither Religion or affection. For who≈øoever thinkes that Spaine and Au≈øtria have any kindne≈øs
for us more than them≈øelves, hath a faith far larger than my fancy.

There is another Objection again≈øt our clo≈øing with England for Religions-≈øake, from their Epi≈øcopall Church-Government; which if it were not mentioned by ≈øome to the prejudice of my a≈ø≈øertion, I ≈øhould have pa≈ø≈øed over as incon≈øiderable. For.

1. This is onely an accidentall difference in the ≈øame Religion, and not a different kinde of Religion, as Popery is. And a difference in the externall forme of Government onely; not in the ≈øub≈øtantialls and vitalls of Religion. For we both agree in the ≈øame Confe≈ø≈øion of Faith, and in all the e≈ø≈øentialls of the Reformed Religion.
2. A very great part of the King of England's Subjects are Presbyterians, as is well knowne.

3. Although Epi≈øcopacy be the Church Government, ≈øetled by Law in the three Kingdoms, yet his-Maje≈øty indulges publique liberty to Presbyterians, and other Non-conformi≈øts. So that we need not doubt but he will much more to us, that Church Government which is ≈øetled among≈øt us.

4. New-England, and ≈øeveral other Plantations belonging to his Maje≈øty of great Brittaine, have allwayes enjoyed, and ≈øtill do their own Church-Governement freely; and therefore we need not feare that ours ≈øhould be denied us.

5. Allthough the Church Governement of the≈øe Provinces be Presbyterian, yet as to its vitall power and admini≈øtration in ≈øeverall places, it hath for ≈øundry yeares la≈øt pa≈øt rather been Era≈øtian. The Magi≈øtrates frequently a≈ø≈øuming that power here, which the Bi≈øhops do there. In ≈øo much that I que≈øtion whether the Presbyterians may not have more hopes, that their di≈øcipline ≈øhould be rai≈øed; then feares that it ≈øhould be ruined under England. Gralloe, contra Apollodium 1646. Lucti Anti≈øtii de Jure Eccle≈øia≈øticor. l. 1665. Politike di≈øcour≈øen. l. 4. over Kerkelike Sacken. What crying up the Magi≈øtrates power circa ≈øacra, and what decrying the Mini≈øters, both by word and writing. Anti≈øtius tells us in the fronti≈øpece of his booke, that whatever right divine or humane is attributed to the Mini≈øters or they a≈ø≈øume to them≈øelves, is either fal≈øely and impiou≈øly a≈øcribed to them, or is onely from the Rulers of the Republique or city where they are ≈øetled. What applauding of Hobs's Leviathan, now tran≈ølated into Latin and Dutch. What frequent interpo≈øing in Eccle≈øia≈øticall affaires, and how mi≈øerably the hone≈øt Mini≈øter in the Hague was handled, may be ≈øeen in Aitzma. Many were afraid of a ≈øtorme falling upon the. Mini≈øters, if our enemies had not faln upon us. What cro≈ø≈øing the Churches in the Election of their Pa≈øtors, and exerci≈øe of their Governement hath been at Rotterdam, and other places, is too well knowne, and being reformed, I wi≈øh whats pa≈øt might be buried in oblivion. div.head: Sect. 5. The ≈øecond Argument taken from Liberty. Wherein the different kinds, and degrees of Liberty under all ≈øorts of Governement, are declared; and the probability of our enjoying greater freedome under England than France, argued.
div.p:
IT will further appeare our intere≈øt, to be under England rather than France, in regard of our Liberty. Which next to true Religion and life, is the greate≈øt ble≈ø≈øing be≈øtowed on man-kind. Now for our clearer proceeding herein, we mu≈øt
1. Shew what kind of Liberty is here meant.
2. Wherein it con≈øi≈øts, and the mea≈øures thereof.
3. Accommodate the≈øe to the matter in hand.

For the fir≈øt. We meane not here Per≈øonall Liberty: either morally con≈øidered in oppo≈øition to coaction; or civilly; either in oppo≈øition to confinement, as we u≈øually take it; or to ≈ølavery, as the Civilians. 2. Brutus in≈øtituit. For I well know, that to whom≈øoever we ≈øubmit, this liberty is lo≈øt. Much le≈øs 3. For Licentiou≈øne≈øs. As Tully ≈øayes well,Pro Cluent. Legum ideirco omnes ≈øervi ≈øumus, ut liberie≈ø≈øe po≈ø≈øimus. But 4. That publick liberty which a people have under their Government, (of what kind ≈øoever it is) as it is taken in oppo≈øition to publick oppre≈ø≈øion. Now Secondly wherein this con≈øi≈øts, and how to mea≈øure the ≈øame, is harder to di≈øcover and determine; in regard we can meet with no guides, that have gone this way. For the Civil Law, which is copious concerning all other Dominions, is ≈øilent in this of Soveraignty; and being calculated for the Meridian of Monarchs, leaves them free to make their Subjects ≈øo, more or le≈øs at their plea≈øure: Hi≈øtorians onely relate what freedom ≈øuch and ≈øuch people had under ≈øuch and ≈øuch Rulers: and the Writers of Policy, and particular Republicks, compare the peoples liberty under the ≈øeveral forms of Government, and commend this or that State for the ≈øame. And the≈øe are all the helps we have: which are in the next degree to nothing
We will therefore pa≈øs them all by, and freely follow our own judgment; in ≈øhewing joyntly both the nature of liberty, and the mea≈øures thereof. But we mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily here premi≈øe.

list.item: 1. That though all ought to pay the homage of ≈øubjection, to that lawful government under which they live; yet none ought ≈øo to be wedded to any forme, as to think the ≈øubjects of all others not free. Which Ari≈øtotle long ≈øince ob≈øerved,Politic. l. 6. c. 2. V. Arni≈øoeus de rep. l. 2. c. 7. ¬ß. 2. n.75. to be the vulgar error in Democracy. For though it well becomes a vertuous Wife, to e≈øteem her own Husband, the be≈øt head ≈øhe can have; and accordingly to be guided by him: yet if ≈øhe will cen≈øure all other Wives, for meer ≈ølaves; all her neighbours round about her, will ring her a peale of indignation.

2. That the be≈øt way to judge of peoples liberty is by con≈øidering it in reference to Soveraignty. For all ≈øubjection and government being relatives; and Subject, liberty con≈øi≈øting, in ≈øuch a manner of ≈øubjection to the Supreme Powers, as is free and not ≈ølavi≈øh; the one is ea≈øily knowne by the other. So that if we duly con≈øider Supremacy, we may di≈øcerne, whether the Subjects be free or no by the manner, and the degrees of their freedom, by the mea≈øure of their ≈øubjection.

3. That we mu≈øt di≈øtingui≈øh between actual liberty. or freedom from oppre≈ø≈øion; and legal liberty by con≈øtitution. For freedom may be con≈øidered either in regard of morall power, or government which is the exerci≈øe thereof; and that both ≈øeverally, and joyntly. For a people free by Law, may be oppre≈ø≈øed by their Rulers; and a people not legally free, may be actually ≈øo by their Governors grace. So that actuall liberty alone, is onely under ab≈øolute Powers, legal under limited and mixed, and both under Governments which proceed regularly, in the Sphere of Power wherein they are placed, and are not planetary in their motions. Having premi≈øed the≈øe things; we ≈øhall now proceed to lay down certain rules, whereby every vulgar capacity may judge, of the nature of liberty and the degrees thereof, under any kind of Soveraignty what≈øoever. Whether it re≈øide in a ≈øingle per≈øon, or in a plurality; either ab≈øolute, or limited in regard of its mea≈øure; or for the manner ≈øimple or mixed; either of two or three e≈øtates, equally or unequally, and from whatever priority or predominant part denominated, Monarchy, Ari≈øtocracy, or Democracy, according to the con≈øtitution of every Nation.

div.p:
And the general rule is this. The greater power in the Soveraignty, the le≈ø≈øer liberty in the Subjects; and the le≈øs power in the Soveraignty, the more liberty in the Subjects. It is not my pre≈øent work to determine, whether of the≈øe is better for the whole. The Polititians pens have ≈øufficiently ventilated that que≈øtion; u≈øually a≈øcribing more ≈øtrength and ≈øtability to the former, and more common pro≈øperity to the latter; though often concluding, either through favour or fear and fl ‚Ä¢ ttery, that that Government under which they live, de≈øerves above all to weare the garland I ≈øhall therefore onely ≈øay this, that ≈øeeing extreames are alwayes dangerous; a golden meane is
that, which makes a golden age, both to Soveraigns and Subjects.

Now although I judge this rule alone, ≈øufficient for our pre≈øent purpo≈øe; yet in regard ≈øome perhaps, may be plea≈øed with ≈øo large a pro≈øpect, as the liberty of all Nations in all ages of the world; we ≈øhall take a fuller view thereof; and the rather, becau≈øe it will be of u≈øe to us hereafter, not onely in this but the following Sections. And for this end will begin at the bottom, that ≈øo a≈øcending by degrees, we may behold both it and them the better.

1. A people under ab≈øolute power, are not truly and legally free, but onely permi≈ø≈øively and precariou≈øly. Becau≈øe their liberty is not from Law, but onely founded in their Governors favor. So that they are liable to all oppre≈ø≈øion, although they are ≈øometimes as actually free, and little oppre≈ø≈øed, as tho≈øe that live under other Governments.

And this liberty, as to the certainty thereof, is more or les according to the degrees of ab≈øolute power. Where the Rulers will, is the peoples Law; freedom is an Embryo, rather than formed: when they make Laws, whereby Subjects are at more certainty; it then becomes a foetus: and when they oblige them≈øelves, to rule by tho≈øe Laws; the child is borne, and may cry out of violence and oppre≈ø≈øion. This liberty, how ≈ømall ≈øoever, and uncertaine of life, hath yet many witne≈ø≈øes to avouch its name; which we find al≈øo regi≈øtred in Antiquity. So that who≈øoever denies the ≈øame; mu≈øt call all tho≈øe ≈ølaves, who lived under the Ea≈øtern and Roman Empires of old, and the Turks and Per≈øians at this day.

2. Under limited power, the people have a legall liberty, which is greater or les, according to the Laws, con≈øtitutions, or contracts, whereby the power is limited. This liberty being ≈øupported by Law, not voluntarily made by the Governors them≈øelves, and alterable at their plea≈øure (as in ab≈øolute power) but nece≈ø≈øarily conde≈øcended to by them that will governe, makes the ≈øubjection of a people tolerable And if the Fathers in power plea≈øe to fo≈øter them, they want not for nece≈ø≈øaries, though they abound not in ≈øuperfluities. But I confes, if this freedom meet with a churli≈øh ≈øtepfather, and hath neither guardian not friends to maintain its right; then its forced to keep private at home, and dare ≈øcarce appear in publike; which makes their pre≈øent condition mi≈øerable. For liberty once lamed by power, is not unlike to a labouring man, that hath his leg broken; who till it be ≈øound, Is thereby confined to his own cottage, or cralls but abroad to beg with his crutches.
3. Tho≈øe that live under a mixed power, have more or les liberty according to the temperament thereof.

If mixt of Monarchie and Acri≈øtocracy onely, the common peoples liberty is according to their Laws. And is more ≈øecured by this compo≈øition, than in a ≈øimple governement, though limited; becau≈øe one is a check to the
exorbitancy of the other. For though every mixt power be limited, yet every limited power is not mixt. In this Government, though the Nobility, ≈øhould as Cedars ≈øhelter the under≈øhrubs, from the ≈øtorms of the ≈øuperior order; yet both Hi≈øtorie and experience ≈øhews us, that often times (I ≈øay not allwayes) the Peeres care not to be their Princes Va≈ø≈øalls, that ≈øo the re≈øt of the people may be theirs.

Monarchie, Ari≈øtocracy, and Democracy; or onely of the two latter; for I never read or heard of a State compounded of the two extreames.

Now the Supreme Power con≈øi≈øts e≈øpecially (I ≈øay not onely)

6. In making War and Peace with others. So then as a people partake in the≈øe, their freedom is accordingly to be accounted of. And here liberty is come to maturity; and if ≈øhe be mode≈øt, and keep within her bounds, and fall not into wanton licentiou≈øne≈øs; ravi≈øhes the eyes of all ≈øpectators, filling their mouthes with her prai≈øes, and their mindes with admiration.
But it is high time that we ha≈øten unto the third particular propo≈øed, which is the accommodation of the≈øe, to the ≈øubject matter we have in hand.

Fir≈øt then, it is well known, that there is a very va≈øt difference in the liberty of the Subjects of the≈øe two Crowns. The common people under the King of England have 1. Tho≈øe 2. under the Crown of England have the election of Magi≈øtrates generally in Corporations, and ≈øome under Officers in the Country, which cannot be removed without due proce≈øs of Law. 3. 2. Hence we may infer a fair probability, of enjoying more liberty under the Crown of England than France. I know our freedom will not nece≈ø≈øarily follow from the premi≈øes; for that which is legal, will depend upon ≈øuch conditions, as ≈øhall be either previou≈øly agreed upon, or after con≈øented unto: yet I leave every one to judge, which is likelie≈øt to grant us the be≈øt; not only for our Religion, but liberty in our Per≈øons, Priviledges and E≈øtates; as al≈øo who≈øe Government is mo≈øt likely to defend the ≈øame, and make us thereby al≈øo actually free.

If it be argued, that the French King may give us more liberty than his other Subjects; and the King of England le≈øs. The reply is ea≈øie; that we rea≈øon not from the power of either, or what they can and may do; but what in all appearance they will do. Although tho≈øe that hold it for a

But we neither de≈øire to di≈øpute the Prerogative of Princes, much le≈øs of ≈øuch a mighty Monarch; nor indeed are we of their opinion herein, and therefore take it for granted, that he as well as the King of England, may grant us as full and ample liberty, as He ≈øhall think fit in His Royal plea≈øure. 1. We cannot flatter our ≈øelves into hopes, that our condition ≈øhould be better than either of tho≈øe two Kings (which ≈øoever we ≈øubmit unto) natural Sujects. 2. The many examples we have before us, of ≈øuch Countries as France hath gained, keeps our fears continually waking. 3. If any have neither li≈øt nor lei≈øure, to look into the Hi≈øtories of former times; the pre≈øent age will furni≈øh them ≈øufficiently, with examples

But if they remain ≈øo incredulous, that all the Beacons that are fired about them, makes them not fear; and that they will believe nothing, which they them≈øelves do not feel: I wi≈øh that experience (which wi≈øe men call the Mi≈øtre≈øs of Fools) convince them not of their folly, when it is too late; and their condition become ≈øo mi≈øerable, that its fitter to be drawn covered with a ≈øorrowful veil, by ≈øome Timanthes's Pencil, than to be lively ≈øet forth in its ≈øad colours, or de≈øcribed by the Pen of an impartial Hi≈øtorian. For my part I profe≈øs that none honours the worth and gallantry of the French Nation more than my ≈øelf, yet I would loth come under its power: for the rea≈øon which the Fox gives the Lion in the Fable,

4. We think we have rea≈øon to be afraid not only for our per≈øons, and pur≈øes; but even for our lives, and all tho≈øe things which may make us mi≈øerable; not only in regard of the French, but our ≈øelves. How were mo≈øt mens hearts filled with fear, many with horror, and ≈øome with de≈øpair; to ≈øee their Country become an Aceldama; and ≈øo many thou≈øands forced through a Red Sea of blood, to find their pa≈ø≈øage to the Land of Canaan! I conclude therefore, that if they who enjoyed le≈øs liberty than we, could ≈øo little endure Servitude; we ≈øhall be much le≈øs able to endure it, who have enjoyed far more freedom then they. div.head: Sect. 6. The third Argument which preponderates for England, is the pre≈øervation of our E≈øtates: in regard of Souldiers violence, Governors Impo≈øitions, Publick Debts by Obligation, and Revenues of the Romi≈øh Church.
div.p: WE proceed now to ≈øhew, that its better to be under England in regard of our E≈øtates. And to this I give the precedency, becau≈øe the enjoyment of Riches is the end for which, and Trade only the means by which, we labour to obtain them. Now if it can be made apparent, that we can neither get, nor keep ≈øuch E≈øtates under France, as we can under England: there are none ≈øo regardle≈øs herein (whatever they are of Religion and Liberty) but will ea≈øily grant the truth of our Conclu≈øion.

1. It is better for us, ≈øay they, to be under France, becau≈øe England and and we are Competitors for Trade.

And though Free≈øland hath not declared, ≈øo that if they ≈øhould come to the utmo≈øt extremity, we know not but they might happily incline to England al≈øo; yet becau≈øe that is uncertain, we will be liberal in granting our Adver≈øaries even that which they cannot prove, and take to our ≈øelves only that we can, and ≈øo proceed upon infallible grounds.

Nor let any one here ≈øtop me, and ≈øay that in taking it for granted that Zeeland will be Engli≈øh, I may be mi≈øtaken, for they may beat off their enemies and defend them≈øelves. I grant it, although by the way let me ≈øay it, I ≈øee but little likelihood of that; for of above 100 Companies they pay, there is as yet not one in their principalle≈øt Ilands (though how it comes ≈øo, becomes not me to enquire) but the thing is to me matter of admiration. But I will ≈øhew you how I rea≈øon; not from the War, that England will conquer Zeeland, nor from the Agreement betwixt the two Crownes, which yet is generally ≈øaid brings us under that: but upon ≈øuppo≈øal that we are tired out with the War, and come to treat with our enemies (for I hope no man is ≈øo mad, as to think the≈øe Provinces will as ∆≤trecht, call them in, and after make what tearms we can get, but treat with them with our weapons in our hands) Zeelands not only Declaration, but Inclination carries them for England. So that which way ≈øoever we take conque≈øt by our enemies, their di≈øpo≈øing of us, or our own di≈øpo≈øal of our ≈øelves, Zeeland is ≈øtill Engli≈øh. So that upon the ≈øuppo≈øition of inability to defend our ≈øelves, we are morally certain, that Zeeland will fall to England: and our Adver≈øaries uncertain, that Holland and Frie≈øland will choo≈øe France. But we will grant them all they can rea≈øonably de≈øire, viz. that the≈øe two Provinces make ≈øuch a choice, and thereupon proceed to the ballancing of Powers.

Now in Naval ≈øtrength, Zeeland hath the proportion of a ≈øixt part in
this Republick; there being 5 Admiralities, wherein Am≈øterdam hath a double rate, we will ≈øuppo≈øe any number for a Fleet greater or le≈øs to be ≈øet out by them. For example, the States equip a Fleet of 72 Sail herein.
