div.p: Yea in the la≈øt War I find in the Li≈øt A. 1666. (which by the way, I wonder any Admiralities ≈øhould publi≈øh, and perceive there is none now) that Zeeland, was a greater ≈øhare than Frie≈øland both in Ships and Men.

Although I know in the quota or Tax to the Publick, Frie≈øland is more: but that is becau≈øe of their greater ≈øhare in the Land, which is a certain revenue, and Trade only a contingency. In ≈øtrength then at Sea we ≈øee, that Zeeland, at le≈øt ballances Frie≈øland if not more, ≈øhould that Province prove French, and this is ≈øufficient for my pre≈øent purpo≈øe.

Now let us look abroad, and we ≈øhall as clearly find, that Spain comes into the Engli≈øh ≈øeale. For which way ≈øoever France take, Spain mu≈øt take the contrary. Nay in this ca≈øe, Spain is as much concerned as England. For if France have the≈øe Provinces entirely, how ≈øhall they alone be able to bring home their American Trea≈øure? They know to their ≈øorrow, what they have lo≈øt formerly by the Dutch taking their Plate-fleets; and what an extraordinary charge and hazard they had to defend them. And ≈øhall we not then think, that they will rather venture to the utmo≈øt with the Engli≈øh; than let us intercept their Trea≈øure, and after ≈øome years be ma≈øter of their Mines? It is true, if I was led as the world is u≈øually, to judge by news, which hath been for ≈øome months that Spain and England are breaking, all this was frivolous; but I make my mea≈øures from rea≈øons of State, which tells me, that they will not, becau≈øe they mu≈øt not, and they mu≈øt not, becau≈øe it is their mutual Intere≈øt, and it is their Intere≈øt, becau≈øe otherwi≈øe they cannot ballance France, but will both in time be ruined. So then you ≈øee clearly, that upon ≈øuppo≈øition that Holland be French, it will be England and Spain again≈øt France and Holland, and ≈øo we are again ballanced.

We are thus far upon ≈øure grounds, we ≈øhall now proceed to that which is not much le≈øs certain, if we rightly con≈øider. And that is, that Denmark in all probability will become al≈øo our Enemies, if we take France ≈øo far for our Friends, as to make him our Ma≈øter. Let us but well ob≈øerve a few fundamental Maxims of State, which every Nation according to their Intere≈øt frame for their Government, and it will much help us to make a
right judgment in all ≈øuch ca≈øes. Now this is one of that Kingdoms, Not to ≈øuffer any one to be ab≈øolute Soveraign of Trade and Navigation if they can po≈ø≈øibly prevent it. For the revenues of that Crown mo≈øtly con≈øi≈øting of toll in the Sound; we cannot imagine the Danes ≈øuch dullards, but they know who ever is ≈øo, will ≈øoon open that pa≈ø≈øage, and make it as free as the water it ≈øelf between the North and Baltick Seas. And then the King may ≈øit in's hou≈øe at Gluckstadt, and take toll of Boats that pa≈øs in the Elve; in≈øtead of Copenhagen, and his Ca≈øtle of Croneberg, where now he takes toll of all ≈øhips in the Sound.

I fore≈øee it will be ≈øaid, that Sweden will ballance Denmark, if that ≈øhould be ≈øo. But ≈øee then what work this Trade will make in the world. And this is wholly uncertain: nay, Intere≈øt will rather incline to the contrary. For though Sweden be none of the riche≈øt in Trade, yet have they their ≈øhare to lo≈øe as well as the re≈øt. And the Revenues of that Crown con≈øi≈øting much in Copper, (which hath occa≈øioned their Armies ≈øpoiling all the Mines of that Metal in Germany, and where≈øoever they could, on purpo≈øe to enhance their own) they know very well that pains might have been ≈øpared, if Commerce ≈øhould have an ab≈øolute Monarch; and that with all the Chimi≈øtry that they can u≈øe, they ≈øhall not be able to extract ≈øilver and gold out of that Mettal, when one only Chapman comes to the market. Be≈øides their Bremi≈øh and other Territories on this ≈øide the Baltick, will ≈øoon lye a bleeding, they know; if France's Sword comes to wound the Roman Eagle, and his race. It may be ≈øome may ≈øay the Dane dares not for fear of lo≈øing that we are indebted to him. But who knows not that it is better to lo≈øe a part, than the whole. And if blows be a way of paying of debts, we may happily have Portugal ≈øo to pay us.

3. Having thus ballance the apparent ≈øtrength of both ≈øides, we ≈øhall proceed to ≈øome other con≈øiderations, concerning the ≈øame. For it is not enough to con≈øider power ab≈øolutely, but al≈øo the management thereof; for le≈øs powers well managed, are u≈øually prevalent above greater. And herein are many things, which in my judgment, were we an over-match for them, which you ≈øee is not ≈øo, would render our ruining their Naval power, and con≈øequently their Traffick impracticable. As 1. Suppo≈øing we are under France, ≈øhall their whole Fleet con≈øtantly be here, and leave the French Coa≈øt naked, or ≈øhall they from thence come to joyn with us for our Sea expeditions? If the former, France is ≈øubject continually to be mole≈øted and diverted from England; and if the latter to be intercepted, by rea≈øon of their ≈øituation. 2. Who ≈øhall have the direction of Naval Affairs, is to me very con≈øiderable. Whether the French alone, or conjoyntly with the Dutch; for that the latter only ≈øhould be intru≈øted, is not to be imagined. The former way is liable to mi≈øcarry through unskilfulne≈øs, the latter through jealou≈øies and di≈ø≈øentions. 3. Where ≈øhall Mariners be had for our Fleets? ≈øhall the French pre≈øs here as in their own Kingdom? If ≈øo, I fore≈øee, we ≈øhall ≈øoon lo≈øe our Sea-men. Or ≈øhall they only u≈øe
Volunteers? Then their number will be ≈ømall, becau≈øe the French pay is not great. I might mention other particulars, as the French and Dutch Officers di≈øcord. The manner of payments, and from whence, &c. But the≈øe are enow to ≈øhew us, that which way ≈øoever we look there's nothing but difficulty and danger ≈øtares us in the face.

4. But we have yet that which is more momentous, and that is the ≈øituation of Great Britain. For could we knock their men in the head, as ea≈øily as our Borinne's their eggs; and ≈øink their Ships, as if they were ≈øhells; yet we cannot po≈ø≈øibly remove the I≈øland. Which is,
1. Not only nigh unto us, but over again≈øt us, ≈øo that we cannot look out, but we are upon them.
2. So ≈øituated, that ≈øhould we bear them and their A≈ø≈øociates, (which is not ea≈øie in equal powers) they can ≈øtill manage a War de≈øtructive to us. And what good will it do any but the envious, to ruipe others, if they be ruined them≈øelves? For with a few Ships in the Chanel, wherein they have Harbours all along, to go in and out at plea≈øure; they will force us continually to ≈øail with great Convoys, or we ≈øhall be forced to fall into their hands. And the like may be ≈øaid of the Northern pa≈ø≈øage by the Orcades, where a few Ships will ob≈øtruct our Trade. Now how great a prejudice this is to Traffick, I leave all knowing men to judge. For by this means. No ≈øingle Ships, nor ≈ømall numbers can ≈øail. Re≈øtraint will be laid upon going out but in great Fleets, and with ≈øufficient Convoys. Many will be nece≈ø≈øitated to lie idle, and at great expences to wait for their Company, whil≈øt they could ≈øometimes have performed their voyage. And Merchants lo≈øe particular de≈øigns, which are u≈øually the greate≈øt profit, to ≈øuch as are able rightly to manage them.
3. In ≈øtorms and tempe≈øts we ≈øhall be frequently forced into their Harbours, and ≈øo fall as a prey into their mouths.

5. Britain and Ireland being I≈ølands, are not ea≈øily invaded, and ≈øo diverted by a Land War, but that they may ≈øolely attend to a Maritime, when they are once engaged therein. Whereas France being on the Continent, is ≈øubject to inva≈øion from Spain on ≈øeveral ≈øides. Which was one rea≈øon, why our Ance≈øtors preferred the guardian≈øhip of England, before that of France.

6. Tangier in the mouth of the Streights, will be no ≈ømall prejudice to our Mediterranean Trade. Which if the mould or harbour can be made firm, will prove of great concernment to the Engli≈øh Crown, and a ≈øtrong curb to all their enemies Traffick. And here I might adde, Cadiz, and all the Coa≈øt of Spain; for if we be French, no wi≈øe man (I think) will doubt, but we ≈øhall have Spain our enemies again.
And the≈øe things I think are abundantly ≈øufficient to di≈ømount our Adver≈øaries confidence, of carrying away the Trade from England, if we ≈øhould come under the power of France.
3. Another grand Argument again≈øt us is, that we are more likely to enjoy Peace under France than England.

Peace (I confe≈øs) is an invaluable ble≈ø≈øing. How many and great mi≈øeries doth it free us from! Blood≈øhed, violence to our Per≈øons and E≈øtates, unquietne≈øs, and almo≈øt all manner of troubles. How many and great mercies doth Peace bring along with it! It is both the mother that bears, and the nur≈øe that brings up all our temporal ble≈ø≈øings. It gives us mercies, the freedom of enjoying them, and ≈øweetens their enjoyment. It contains liberty, plenty, equity, tranquility, plea≈øure, and ≈øafety. So that he was a mad man that ≈øhould not chu≈øe Peace. But I fear our coming under France, is neither the way to procure Peace, nor the means to pre≈øerve it. And that we by ≈øo doing, ≈øhall but have Ixions fate in the Fable, embrace a cloudy and tempe≈øtuous War, in≈øtead of the fair and beloved Juno of Peace.

1. Let it be con≈øidered; that if we have Peace by Land, we have War by Sea: which is to leap out of the frying-pan into the fire. It is an old and a good political axiom, Ex duobus malis minus e≈øt eligendum; Theological it was never, for in Divinity, Nullum malum e≈øt eligendum. Now if we rightly mea≈øure our Intere≈øt, we ≈øhall find a Land War much more eligible for us upon many accounts, which I need not here to mention, they being ea≈øily imagined by all wi≈øe men. For ≈øhould it be granted, that for the pre≈øent the two Crowns accord and we have Peace: it will either be ≈øuch a one as will ruine us, or cannot be la≈øting to be ≈øure; but in a very few years will nece≈ø≈øarily come to the ballance I have mentioned of Spain and England again≈øt France and Holland.

2. Let us therefore examine their grounds; that ≈øo we may ≈øee before us, and not run our ≈øelves blindfold into de≈øtruction. Which ≈øo far as I can di≈øcern are the≈øe four. The power and prevalency of his Arms. His trea≈øure to maintain them. His nearne≈øs to us. And his Allies.

Fir≈øt for the power and prevalency of his Arms. 1. It is true his numbers are great, both in Arms and in the Kingdom of France. The great advantages he hath, by the largene≈øs, compactne≈øs, ≈øituation, and ≈øoil of his Dominions; the infinite number of Nobility and Gentry for Cavalry, and the populou≈øne≈øs of his Cities and Provinces for Infantry, which capcitate him above all the Princes of Europe, to enlarge his Empire; I well know, and willingly grant.

But what relates to the Kingdom of France concerns not us Netherlanders in this ca≈øe further than as to his Arms and power to defend us. Now in my rea≈øon the greater power in the Soveraign, Sect. 5. the le≈øs liberty in the Subject, as we have already ≈øhown. So that the more numerous his Armies, and ≈øo much the wor≈øe. Doth not France groan under this burden, and ≈øhall we de≈øire to do ≈øo, or help to ea≈øe them by bearing part thereof on our backs? If we be ≈øo kind, I dare engage we may have it all, and a thou≈øand thanks from that Kingdom. Which is ≈øo wearied with it, that above one half of them (if my intelligence greatly deceive me not) would rejoyce to ≈øee it le≈ø≈øened, though it were with ≈øome lo≈øs to the honour of the Nation. But becau≈øe I write not to be known, but to better the world, and with
my bucket of water to help to quench the Flames, that threaten de≈øtruction to the Prote≈øtant Intere≈øt; I ≈øhall de≈øire all intelligent per≈øons to enquire of tho≈øe that under≈øtand France, or have come lately thence; and then let them con≈øider if their condition be de≈øirable. If a numerous Army lies quartered upon us, ≈øhall we not both be kept under by them, and eaten up of them? And although they be paid in the Kings name, yet mu≈øt not we find our ≈øhare of the money? I never yet read or heard of any wi≈øe people, that de≈øired their Prince ≈øo potent, for fear he ≈øhould oppre≈øs them. A due Mediocrity hath always been counted be≈øt. Let any one read the Greek and Roman Hi≈øtorians, or any others that are wi≈øely writ: and he ≈øhall find, if he duly ob≈øerve, that the Princes Potency hath always been the peoples jealou≈øie.

2. It is al≈øo true, that he hath been ≈øucce≈øsful in his Arms again≈øt us, beyond mo≈øt mens imaginations, and perhaps even his own hopes and expectations. But if all things be rightly con≈øidered, it is no ≈øuch wonder as the world makes it. Our Wars by Sea; our inte≈øtine Divi≈øions; the cowardi≈øe of ≈øome; the corruption of many; and our multiplicity of Garri≈øons, whereby our Forces were ≈øo parcel'd, that fighting ≈øeverally they were ea≈øily vanqui≈øhed; together wi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øeveral other cau≈øes which concurr'd under the hand of Divine Ju≈øtice, makes it no wonderment to wi≈øe and con≈øiderate men. 3. Nor will this evince our defence. For it hath often been experimented, that tho≈øe that have won much in a little time, have lo≈øt it again in le≈øs. How did the ≈øame French Nation under Charles the 8. over-run mo≈øt part of Italy in a little time, and quickly lo≈øt it, as the many Hi≈øtorians of both Nations relate! And ≈øo may this (if it plea≈øe God, and we manage our work wi≈øely) like a thunderclap and ≈øudden fla≈øh of lightning, afright and a≈øtoni≈øh us, more than hurt us, as I ≈øhall ≈øhew hereafter.

4. If France goes on, the world grows ≈øo jealous of their greatne≈øs, that they may po≈ø≈øible have work enough; when their hand is again≈øt every one, and every one again≈øt them; and then where ≈øhall be our peace and defence? It is known by all that know former times, how in the Roman Monarchy when they were di≈øtre≈ø≈øed at home, they ≈øtill called their Forces from abroad, and left their conquered Provinces to ≈øhift for them≈øelves, as I might in≈øtance in Spain, France, England, and many others both Ea≈øtern and We≈øtern. And indeed it always is thus; ≈øo that ≈øhould France be fallen into by Spain, or England, or the Empire, or Italy, or other ≈øeveral of the≈øe joyntly, or ≈øhould they fall into Civil Wars, which are more frequent there than any, yea I think I may ≈øay all the Kingdoms in Europe; in what condition ≈øhould we then be? Truly I will tell you, I think fighting
with the French, and more eager to be rid of them, then many are now to receive them. If any one ≈øay, but would you have us entertain the Engli≈øh? I ≈øay no, but pre≈øerve our own freedom by complying with them as I ≈øhall ≈øhew hereafter.

5. If we will e≈øpou≈øe all the quarrels of France we may po≈ø≈øibly have more than enow; and ≈øuch as may prove our ruin, rather than ≈øafety and ≈øecurity. Our Marriners have their Wars by Sea, our citizens and Souldiers by Land. Our Merchants Trade to pay their money, and all to rai≈øe France to the univer≈øal Monarchy, to the ruin of the Reformed Religion, and al≈øo the greate≈øt part of Chri≈øtendom. 6. I ≈øee no need we have to fear all his power and prevalency, if we will do our duty, and quit our ≈øelves as men for our Country. And if we do, upon our friend≈øhip with the Crown of England, we may have Souldiers enow out of tho≈øe 3 Kingdoms, which are as good Infantry ≈øurely as French, by their own Hi≈øtorians Confe≈ø≈øion, and it is Foot we want (if any) for the defence of our Garri≈øons. And be≈øides that they are not ≈øo likely to be remanded, as tho≈øe of France; tho≈øe Kingdoms being Ilands, le≈øs liable to inva≈øion, and le≈øs likely to be engaged in foreign, or to be involved in Dome≈øtick Wars.

Secondly, for his trea≈øure, it cannot be denied to be very great. But this is rather again≈øt, than for our Adver≈øaries. For the richer the Soveraign the poorer the ≈øubject. And I never knew any people yet, that de≈øired to have their Prince ≈øo rich, e≈øpecially when it comes out of their own pockets. I will not meddle with the di≈øpute of the Greeks O≈øtraci≈øme, nor that of Politicians, whether poverty or riches in the Soveraign be better for the ≈øubject. When neither the Prince may be jealous of his people for their Riches, nor they of him for his Trea≈øures; but that they may mutually depend on each other, for the good of the whole. For as it is difficult to determin, what the Magi≈øtrate may not demand, in ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity; ≈øo is it ea≈øie to conclude, that he ought not to impoveri≈øh his people when there is none, and make him≈øelf rich by their ruins. Nor is it imaginable, that he will make France poor, to make us rich. Nor is it credible that if they remain poor, we ≈øhall remain rich. For in all Princes there remain ≈øome jealou≈øies of a conquered people, that they may, upon ≈øome revolution of affaires or other, revolt. And therefore it is their u≈øual practice, by all ways po≈ø≈øible to drain them, and draw their riches home; as the Romans into Italy, and other Conquerors their own Kingdoms; either by bringing it into their own Trea≈øuries, or Native ≈øubjects pur≈øes, or rather both, that ≈øo they may command it upon all occa≈øions.

Thirdly, for their nearne≈øs unto us, we know it too well. And if the
≈øubdued Provinces remain in their hands, ≈øhall find what it is to have ≈øuch neighbors. But otherwi≈øe England is nearer us than France, and can ea≈øilier come to our a≈ø≈øi≈øtance. For the French have not only a long march, but through part of the Empire, which is their enemie, and ≈øo liable to ob≈øtruction. As to the Prince of Liege (or Archbi≈øhop of Colen) Duke of Newburg and others that have permitted this pa≈ø≈øage, they may pay dear enough for it hereafter; as their ≈øubjects, are paying for it at pre≈øent, even to the French them≈øelves. But we are not affraid of all our Adver≈øaries weapons, and therefore will enforce their Argument, by ≈øuppo≈øing all they can de≈øire; That France will keep the≈øe conquered Provinces, and in all probability make new acque≈øts, by ≈øubduing of the Spani≈øh Netherlands. So that if we be not ≈øubject to him, we ≈øhall never be at quiet, but they will continually be as Thorns in our ≈øides.

1. And why may we not as well ≈øuppo≈øe, that if we be under him, we ≈øhall never be at re≈øt for others? For no Potentate in Chri≈øtendom hath more jealous eyes upon him, nor likelier to be continually imployed in Wars. Now what will changing help us, if we better not our condition? For we may ea≈øily fore≈øee, that if we come under France, we ≈øhall have England and Spain again≈øt us by Sea (as we have ≈øaid) and the Germans and Spani≈øh Provinces by Land, and ≈øo ≈øhall be in the ≈øame condition, though not by the ≈øame enemies, that we are now; ground like Corn betwixt the Mil-≈øtones. Yea it is more than probable, that knowing the tickli≈øh condition and mutinous temper of the French Nation, he will bring his Wars into the≈øe Countries and their con≈øines, and ≈øo we ≈øhall again become, the Cock-pit of War for all Europe.

2. I doubt not but he will attacque the Spani≈øh Provinces and ≈øeek to connect them with his conque≈øts, and then incorporate all with France. But it is uncertain what time this may require before they be all under his power. We know not the Articles between the two Crowns, nor are we ≈øure that England and Au≈øtria will ≈øee this work. Many things may fall out, which no mans eye can fore≈øee. The King of France is mortal and may die, and the Dauphin young and ≈øo uncapable to carry on ≈øuch mighty de≈øigns. Or he may meet with a check in his enterpri≈øes, and be ≈øtopt in his further progre≈øs of glory. France is harra≈øt, and weary of Wars, may fall to their former mutinies. The King of Spain may grow more potent. England, Sweden and the Cantons of Switzerland may think them≈øelves concerned, as well as the Empire and Spain, to ≈øtop the growing greatne≈øs of France. The Spani≈øh may divert him in Catalonia and el≈øe where. Sickne≈øs and mortallity may ≈øeize upon his Armies. Factions in his court, di≈øcontents in the Country, tumults in his Kingdom, and many other Accidents may happen, to call him off us, or at lea≈øt nece≈ø≈øitate him to give us rea≈øonable
conditions, and confine him to his own Kingdom. So that 'tis madne≈øs to avoid a pre≈øent mi≈øchief, to run our ≈øelves upon certain ruine.

3. If we had the friend≈øhip of England, we might ≈øoon be in a capacity to defend our ≈øelves again≈øt France, and need not fear the power of their Arms. I do not ≈øay that we alone are able to recover at pre≈øent what we have lo≈øt, without the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of others: But that the≈øe remaining Provinces are able to defend them≈øelves, and either let go the other, or in time po≈ø≈øibly regain them, as we ≈øhall ≈øhew hereafter.

I wi≈øh that the eccho of Fame may follow them, with a clearer ≈øound than the hoar≈øe clamour of the People; and hope that the imbellick Bores that are ready to ≈øtart at the report of a Gun, and ≈øtoop at the whi≈øtling of a Bullet, may, by having dangers familiarized to them, become (as the Fox did with the Lion) undaunted at la≈øt, and under their brave General and Commanders regain our reputation; and ≈øhall heartily pray both for our Senators pro≈øperity, and Souldiers ≈øucce≈øs.

The only con≈øideration that ≈øways with me for conte≈øting for them, if we cannot have them otherwi≈øe, is that of Religion. If therefore this policy, I have pleaded ≈øhould prove Apocryphal; and that our League and Alliance with them, obliges us for them recovery; or that the rules of Chri≈øtian Charity require us, to adventure our own lo≈øs for their ≈øafety: God forbid that I, or a any man el≈øe ≈øhould be again≈øt it; and I hope there are none ≈øo degenerate, but will contribute their be≈øt a≈ø≈øi≈øtance both in pur≈øe and per≈øon to ≈øo good a work. If the Turks will redeem the caged birds to ≈øet them at liberty, let us much more willingly our Chri≈øtian Brethren, and ≈øo committing our cau≈øe to God, pa≈øs thorow the Temple of Vertue, that we may happily come to that of Honour.

Having thus ≈øhewn the impregnablene≈øs of the truth of our cau≈øe, again≈øt the a≈ø≈øaults of its Adver≈øaries; and fought it out with them, in their repre≈øenting the Advantages of being under France, and di≈øadvantages of being under England, and our Replying: It comes now to our turn to be A≈ø≈øailants, wherein we hope to obtain an ab≈øolute conque≈øt, by ≈øhewing them the quite contrary.

Now herein we might be very large, if we would argue from all the ≈øua≈øory and di≈ø≈øua≈øory topicks; as the Hone≈øty of being under England rather than France for the common Intere≈øt of the Prote≈øtant Religion; the Honorablene≈øs thereof for the common good of Chri≈øtendom, who≈øe Intere≈øt it is to oppo≈øe the greatne≈øs of France, as we ≈øhall ≈øhew hereafter: the Equity of this for a≈ø≈øi≈øting our Allies again≈øt France: the po≈ø≈øibility or practicablene≈øs of this only, now that his Highne≈øs is both General and Stadt-holder: and al≈øo from the contrary of the≈øe if we ≈øeek to come under France. But we ≈øhall only in≈øi≈øt upon that of ∆≤tility, becau≈øe that is mo≈øt pet≈øwa≈øive; and that with re≈øpect to our ≈øelves only, the mo≈øt part of men being ≈øo ≈øelfi≈øh, that they prefer their particular before the publick good.

div.head: The di≈øadvantages of being under France, and advantages of being under England.
div.p: 1. Our being under France brings us infallibly unto a War with England and Spain, in ≈øome ≈øhort time at lea≈øt, if not pre≈øently, as we have already ≈øhown. Now how de≈øtructive ≈øuch a War is to our maritime Negotiation, I leave all wi≈øe men to judge, and Merchants e≈øpcially who have the experience thereof.

Whereas on the contrary our being under England, gives us Peace and freedom of Trade by Sea; at lea≈øt incon≈øiderable di≈øturbance in compari≈øon; yea very probably by Land al≈øo; in regard we can ≈øpoil France's Trade, di≈øturb his coa≈øts, divert his de≈øigns, and ballacne his power. For France cannot fight with all Europe. If we be under England, we have Spain, the Empire &c. with us: and if France will fight, we need not fear him. But if that which is ≈øaid be not ≈øufficient (as I ≈øuppo≈øe it is) I am ready to make it apparent, that a Land War is more eligible for this Republick, then one by Sea with ≈øuch potent enemies, and take the utmo≈øt interruption France can make of our Sea-traffick into the ballance.
2. If we come under France we ≈øhall either do it entirely, or partially.

If the former we are ruined in a great mea≈øure in our Commerce, for ≈øuppo≈øing that the Spani≈øh Netherlands fall under France al≈øo, as in all probability they will, and that ≈øpeedily, as even our Adver≈øaries them≈øelves take it for granted; the Scheld will be open and free, and ≈øo Antwerp, Bruxels, Mechlin, Loven, Lier and the other Cities of Brabant, by this means recover part of their former Commerce; which now we deprive them of by Vli≈ø≈øing and Rammekens below, and Lillo above on that River: and Ghant, Cortrick, Rii≈ø≈øel and other Cities of Flanders a part, by the former River being free, and by opening the other pa≈ø≈øage to them, which is now ob≈øtructed at the Sas van Ghant.

Now of how great con≈øequence this is to us, e≈øpecially in regard of Am≈øterdam, which bears now a double proportion in the Admiralties, and almo≈øt the half of the burden of the Taxes of Holland, which is almo≈øt the half of the whole Republick, I leave any one to judge, and e≈øpecially tho≈øe that know the principles of intere≈øt for that great and flouri≈øhing City. I could be very large upon this, in ≈øhewing how the fall of Antwerp was the ri≈øe of Am≈øterdam; how this City prevailed that the other ≈øhould not be taken by the Arms of this Republick; as al≈øo what ≈øome ≈øay it co≈øt them to prevent it; that this was a great inducement to the States, not to enlarge the Republick on the ≈øide of Flanders and Brabant; and what a great motive it was to make peace with Spain, that ≈øo they might prevent ≈øo Potent a Prince as France, from coming ≈øo nigh them upon that quarter, and doing it by power, and how Holland gave ≈øecurity for maintaining the peace, when Zeeland prote≈øted again≈øt the ≈øame: But the≈øe are ≈øo well known in Holland, and the objections again≈øt it ≈øo an≈øwered,Schookius de Pace., that I need not lanch into this Ocean. Now who is ≈øo purblind but he may
fore≈øee, that if we come under France, the Flemi≈øh Merchants, e≈øpecially Papi≈øts, will return and carry their Trade to Antwerp, and many French al≈øo ≈øetle them≈øelves there; the River being much better, the City fit for traffick every way, and having the Popi≈øh Religion publickly profe≈øt, ≈øo that it will ≈øoon conte≈øt with Am≈øterdam for Trade, and carry it ere long; and then Am≈øterdam may ≈øay of Antwerp, as the Ice of the Water, Mater me genuit, mater mox gigniture exme. For we mu≈øt think tho≈øe Cities, and particularly Antwerp, are nearer the Confines of France than Holland; and will be more confided in, being Papi≈øts; ≈øo that they will become both the care and Crown of that King and Kingdom, for their Trade in the≈øe Northern parts of the World. Yea let me ≈øay it, for I know it to be true, this is that the Trading Flamens long for, ≈øeek for, and ≈øhould above all things be glad to ≈øee: ≈øo that in ≈øtead of hindring, they ≈øhall help, all they dare, Frances conque≈øt for this their Intere≈øt.

And if ≈øome of the≈øe Provinces only come under France, and other≈øome under England; what a mi≈øerable condition ≈øhall we be in; by having two ≈øuch potent Princes continually conte≈øting in the mid≈øt of us, ≈øo that by ≈øuch ≈øtrong fits of Colick in our bowels, and Convul≈øions in the whole body, our di≈øea≈øe mu≈øt needs become mortal, and our wounds incurable. Let us ≈øuppo≈øe that which is likelie≈øt, both by the be≈øt intelligence, inclination of the people (as we have ≈øaid formerly) and intere≈øt as we ≈øhall ≈øhew herea≈øter, that Zeeland become Engli≈øh, and Holland, ≈øhould chu≈øe France; and con≈øider the ≈øituation of Zeeland, neer the Sea, and allmo≈øt right over the River of Thames, and both between France and Holland, and betwixt Holland and the Chanel; the Harbours of Vli≈ø≈øing and Ter Vere, into which, the latter e≈øpecially, all Winter long, no with≈øtanding the Ice, is ≈øafe arrival; their genious as well as commodiou≈øne≈øs to Cape: and then judge in what a perilous condition the Trade of Holland will be under France, and what mi≈øerable work will be made among≈øt us. Or let it be ≈øuppo≈øed that there is frend≈øhip between France and England in the enjoying their ≈øeveral ≈øhares (for we will grant all po≈ø≈øibilities, and much more probabilities, our Adver≈øaries can rea≈øonably de≈øire) and how will our mutual traffick be ≈øpoiled, by the impo≈øitions of both Crowns upon commodities; if we ≈øhould pay to the one in Holland and the other in Zeeland, as undoubtedly we mu≈øt. For it is a certain truth, that multiplicity of impo≈øitions, e≈øpecially when great, ≈øpoils merchandi≈øe. And will it not be in Englands power, to open the River, and make it tree for Antwerp, &c. as we have ≈øaid? and in that ca≈øe, where will the va≈øt Commerce of Holland then be?
Whereas on the contrary were we either of the≈øe ways under England, we exclude France and Flanders, and pre≈øerve our Trade to our ≈øelves.

If we be entirely under England; we may ≈øave the Spani≈øh Netherlands, who≈øe Governors are contented with what Commerce they have, rather than lo≈øe all; we may pre≈øerve our ≈øelves from the French neighbourhood;
and thereby al≈øo our Trade from them both.

Or if we be but in part ≈øo; we pre≈øerve the friend≈øhip of the≈øe Provinces, the Trade betwixt us, ≈øecure our intere≈øt both at home and abroad, and command the Commerce of Europe at our plea≈øure.

3. If we come under France, we have not only Spain our Enemy by Sea and Land (as we have ≈øhewn) but the lo≈øs of our Spani≈øh Trade, and the hazarding of our whole Levant Traffick: And if we rightly calculate, that amounts to no ≈ømall part of our Commerce. The Spani≈øh Netherlands, Spain, and their Dominions in Italy, taking off much of our Ea≈øt India and We≈øtern-wares. For as Mu≈øcovy and the other Nothern Nations con≈øume much of our Pepper, and ≈øome hotter Spices, ≈øo the Southern, and Ea≈øtern in the Mediterranean, much of our other Commodities. Now with what ≈øecurity can we either carry them through the Sea, or bring our Silks, Camels-hair, and other of the riche≈øt Commodities we have, from Aleppo, Egypt, and our other Factories for the Turkie Trade, and maintain our Traffick with Venice, Leghorne, and other places in Italy: Seeing the Spaniards be≈øides the ports of Spain, have ≈øo many Havens, and ≈øome I≈ølands in the Adriatick; Sicilia, Sardinia, Majorca and Minorea in the Midland Sea; and Cadiz ≈øo commodiou≈øly ≈øituated at the mouth of the Straits; ≈øome of which have been famous in all Ages for the Arche≈øt Pirates in the whole World. Betwixt the≈øe therefore and the Turks, we are certain of nothing, but of bad Trading, and they good Caping. So that I may conclude with the Poetical Proverb, that he that de≈øires to flie from England, and fall under France for Traffick, Incidit in Scyllam, cupiens vitare Charybdim.

Whereas on the contrary, if we come under England; we certainly ≈øecure our Commerce with Spain, and all the Territories belonging to that Crown. And not only ≈øo, but again≈øt the Turki≈øh Pyrates which infe≈øt tho≈øe Seas, which would be of no ≈ømall advantage to us. For be≈øides that England is at peace with ≈øome of tho≈øe places on the African Coa≈øt, and is in friend≈øhip with the Turki≈øh Empire; how ea≈øie a thing was it for us joyntly, to bring the re≈øt to our own terms? Yea, ≈øo to ≈øubdue them all, and keep them under, that they ≈øhould never be able to di≈øturb us, no nor Chri≈øtendom more by their Caping? And how generous a de≈øign this is and how de≈øtructive to that great and common Enemy of all Chri≈øtians, I leave all wi≈øe men, and well-wi≈øhers to Chri≈øtianity to con≈øider and judge.

4. Our Ea≈øt India Trade, the riche≈øt jewel of this Republick, which hath occa≈øioned us ≈øo much envy, and cau≈øed ≈øo many quarrels and conte≈øts; if we come under France, will run a great Risks to be ruined. Hath not this been their great de≈øign of late years? Have they not for this end erected a Company? And now got footing there, and follow it further, even in this la≈øt year, as we hear, with their greate≈øt endeavours? Nay, is not this the principal motive, which induces them to make this War? I know we need not fear them there, nor all Europe if we have peace here, and can ≈øend them ≈øupplies; We are ≈øo far advanced in that Negotiation;
≈øo ≈øtrong in Forts, Shipping and Souldiers; our men ≈øo accu≈øtomed to the heat of tho≈øe Countries; our Mariners to tho≈øe Coa≈øts; and Merchants to the Languages and Trade of tho≈øe parts. But if we come under France, will not England and Spain ≈øeek continually to intercep our ≈øupplies thither, and our Returns from thence? Will not this put us to va≈øt Charges of Convoys to defend our Ships going and coming in ≈øecurity? Will not ≈øome through ≈øtorms and other accidents when ≈øeparated, unavoidably fall into their hands, as we have often experienced? And will they not always be in one hazard or other from them for ≈øafety? Yea let us ≈øuppo≈øe that all ≈øtands well there, and none of our Ships mi≈øcarry through our Enemies, but ≈øafely Arrive both there and here; where ≈øhall we vent tho≈øe Commodities from thence at the prices they now yield us; when we have ≈øuch Enemies at home, and ≈øuch dangers in carrying them abroad, as we have formerly ≈øhown? Nay, can we rationally think otherwi≈øe, than that the Kingdom of France will have ≈øhare with us there, and the Crown the greate≈øt profit here? So that our Ea≈øt India Actions, as high as they are now may in a little time come as low as tho≈øe of the We≈øt India Company; which was once thought equal with the other, and are now next to nothing: and then many of us, who have mo≈øt of our e≈øtates adventured in the Ea≈øt-Indies Trade, may lo≈øe that we have le≈øt, as we have formerly lo≈øt by the We≈øt-Indies; and no remedy but patience, for we mu≈øt ≈øit down in a ≈øorrowful filence. Herein I have rea≈øon to ≈øpeak feelingly of my fears, being ≈øo concern'd according to the proportion of my ≈ømall e≈øtate; how much, matters none but my ≈øelf, but were it ten times more, I mu≈øt tell you; that though the Actions at this pre≈øent are con≈øiderably above three hundred, I ≈øhall the fir≈øt day I ≈øee we come under France, ≈øell mine willingly for two, rather than keep them, and render many thanks to the buyer into the bargain.

Whereas on the other hand if we come under England, they have formerly had, and ≈øtill have a con≈øiderable ≈øhare in the Ea≈øt India Trade. Their Company and ours accord well, and frequently accommodate each others corre≈øpondence. His Maje≈øty in the former War, in his Declaration, and the Papers pa≈øt between the States General,
A.D. 1664, 1665 and his Envoy Sir George Dawning, infi≈øts upon Poleron one of the Banda I≈ølands, ≈øatisfaction for injuries pa≈øt, with deduction of what we had ≈øuffered, and regulation of Trade for the future; A.D. 1671/2 and his Maje≈øty in his Declaration of this pre≈øent War only mentions the la≈øt, The Regulation of Trade in the Ea≈øt-Indies. Now I per≈øwade my ≈øelf, that neither the States, nor Ea≈øt-India Company will ≈øtick upon the≈øe. For Polleron, if they have it, it can now neither be any great profit to them, nor prejudice us: For a ju≈øt accompting with them, what ju≈øt man can be again≈øt it? Or again≈øt a due and equal Regulation of Trade? that ≈øo all occa≈øions of conte≈øts between the two Nations may be cut off, and wholly prevented for the future. It is true, that reaches not the ≈øuppo≈øal of our being under them, but only ≈øtanding upon equal terms
with them for Trade: and therefore we will come clo≈øe up to the ≈øuppo≈øition in hand.

And herein we ≈øhall proceed with ≈øuch franckne≈øs, that we ≈øhall grant more than our adver≈øaries can rea≈øonably be jealous of; and that is, that the Engli≈øh ≈øhould have half of that Trade with us; and yet ≈øhew that it is better for us then to take in France. For, 1. The Engli≈øh have a con≈øiderable part already, and France but an incon≈øiderable: ≈øo that we mu≈øt, in all probability, part with much more to the latter, and need part with le≈øs to the former. Our fir≈øt capital of the Ea≈øt-India Company, is 64 Tun of Gold, and the Engli≈øh 40. It is true we have Traded both longer and more, and ≈øo have a greater improvement: ≈øuppo≈øe 70 Tun of Gold there, which ordinarily is reckoned about three times in the value when returned hither; and ≈øuppo≈øe as much or more here in goods or money; which va≈øtly exceeds the Engli≈øh: yet it mu≈øt be con≈øidered that we are at greater expences there ≈øeveral ways than they; that we have money at intere≈øt, though incon≈øiderable to what formerly, having pay'd off the la≈øt year above 50, ≈øome ≈øay 60 Tun of Gold. I mu≈øt here ingenuou≈øly confe≈øs, that I have but the forementioned calculations from the cur ‚Ä¢ o≈øity of di≈øcour≈øe, and the credit of others; not upon the authentick authority of the books of both Companies; which I have not lei≈øure now, nor indeed plea≈øure to enquire into; and yet I think I am near the truth, having had the≈øe things from very good hands. I will therefore proceed, and here we are certain, that be≈øides a great ≈øum of money, our Company hath lent the States to carry on this War, which I reckon as an honourable gift, we are like to part with a far greater to purcha≈øe our peace. And though our Actions be far more worth than theirs, for example, a capital Action that gives right to a ≈øuffrage, in the election of the Directors of that Trade being originally 100 l Vlami≈øh, (or 1800 g) and in times of peace 400 l Vl. (or 2400 g) and ≈øometimes 500 l Vl. (or 3000 g) and with them not worth two, or twelve: yet this ari≈øes not ≈øo much from the great emolument, that the Participants here receive more than there, as from the plenty of money here, which ≈øeveral have and know not how otherwi≈øe to improve, the ≈ømall Intere≈øt (u≈øually under 4 per Cento to tho≈øe of good credit) and the dearne≈øs of Land; all which are contrary in England. So that I leave it to any competent and impartial man to judge, (≈øhould it be ≈øo, which yet, I think, none need to fear) whether it is better for us to ≈øupply the Engli≈øh with a le≈øs part, or the French with a greater of that our Trade. For I dare ≈øay, that if England hath a fourth of ours, France hath not an eighth part thereof.
2. How ea≈øie is it for us and England to beat France out of the Ea≈øt-India Tra≈ø≈øek? if we have Wars, or if the French ≈øeek to incroach upon us.

3. Under England we keep our own Chambers of Trade; whereby thou≈øands of Families ≈øub≈øi≈øt in our Cities. All manner of Trades for Shipping
and navigation, Carpenters, Smithes, Sail-makers, &c. All manner of Trade≈ømen for victuals, Bakers, Brewers, Butchers, &c. by their labours at lea≈øt. Whereas if we come under France, and the Spani≈øh Provinces al≈øo, as we may rea≈øonably ≈øuppo≈øe; a great ≈øhare will be removed to Antwerp, there being ≈øo large and magnificent an Ea≈øt-India hou≈øe, and that being nearer France by far. 4. The impo≈øitions of the Crown of England is with con≈øent of the people in Parliament; the rates both inward and outward being ≈øet by law: and ≈øo would be here with con≈øent of the States. Tho≈øe of France arbitrary, and inhan≈øible at plea≈øure. And how great an alteration Cu≈øtoms make in Commerce, I leave all knowing Merchants to judge.
I fore≈øee it will be ≈øaid, that were we under France, we ≈øhould beat England out of the Ea≈øt India Trade, and ≈øo have it wholly to our ≈øelves.
If they would make either the ‚Ä¢ ntecedent or Con≈øequent good, the Argument de≈øerved con≈øideration; bue I know they cannot; for they are both impracticable.

Fir≈øt, We cannot beat them out there, till we have conquered them here: for how ≈øhall we in Wars with them, ≈øpare Ships, Souldiers, &c. to do that? Now what probability there is of conquering them, is formerly declared. The Engli≈øh are rea≈øonably fortified and provided, and will doubtle≈øs be better, if they ≈øee danger approaching. And not only ≈øo, but being in good amity (as I have heard) with tho≈øe Nations where they re≈øide, they would never ≈øuffer our enmity to prevail ≈øo far again≈øt them. Nor if we ≈øhould conquer them there, will all the ≈øpoils fall to our ≈øelves; as ≈øome may po≈ø≈øibly think, who≈øe hopes are po≈øtilion to the Sun, and therefore fancy things beyond the Moon; and bring ≈øuch booties from Ea≈øt to We≈øt upon the wings of their windy imaginations. 5. If we be under France, what ≈øhall become of our Fi≈øhery upon the Coa≈øt of England, and tho≈øe multitudes of Families that depend thereon? I might be large herein from my own Ob≈øervations, having had the humour or curio≈øity (call it what you plea≈øe) to view all the Rivers, Harbors, and almo≈øt Creeks on both the oppo≈øite Coa≈øts, from Thames to Tinmouth, and from the Elve to Oo≈øtend. A diligent per≈øon calculated in the Year 62 the dependants on the Fi≈øhing-trade (I mean not Fi≈øhers only, but al≈øo all employed about their ≈øhipping, Nets, Cask, Salt, &c. with their Attendants at Sea) and reckoned them above 400000. Yea ≈øome have made their number far greater, particularly that learned, wi≈øe, and valiant Knight Sir Walter Rawleigh (whom I parallel with Sir Philip Sidney) in his information of King James, reckons our Ve≈ø≈øels that fi≈øh on the Coa≈øts of Great Britain 3000 and every 20 Bu≈ø≈øes to maintain 8000, which will amount to 1200000. It is ≈øufficient for my pre≈øent purpo≈øe, that I ≈øhew, that our Fi≈øhery is very con≈øiderable, and the friend≈øhip of England for the ≈øame, of far more con≈øequence to us than that of France.

Guicciardine, De≈øcript. generalis Belgii. a very diligent Writer, A. D. 1587 reckons the Herring-Bu≈ø≈øes, that fi≈øh on the Briti≈øh Coa≈øts at lea≈øt 700, and ≈øome ≈øaid many more: and though he include Flanders, yet not the other Fi≈øheries, as Rawleigh doth, and doubtle≈øs of all the Maritime Provinces of this Republick; which the Author of the Intere≈øt of Holland c. 5. erroniou≈øly appropriates to that Province alone, through inadvertency, that Foreigners frequently call all the≈øe United Provinces Hollanders, that being the principal, and all the Spani≈øh, yea formerly all the 17 by the name of Vlamens. div.head: Advantages under England, not to be expected under France.
div.p: 1. By being under England, we retain and encrea≈øe our friend≈øhip with the Empire, German Princes, and free Cities: which are not jealous of Englands affecting the Imperial Crown, as they are of France: and therefore will not prejudice us under the former, as they will certainly in a little time under the latter. Nay I doubt not, but were we under England, they would take courage, and generally appear again≈øt France. So that we ≈øhould hereby greatly promote the common Intere≈øt of Europe.

2. Under England we might have the freedom of the We≈øt-Indie Trade, which would be of great profit to us, many ways. 4. Expences might be ≈øaved in ≈øeveral Conveys, and particularly of the Ea≈øt India Companies. I know very well they will have them return round about, on the back of Ireland, le≈øt they ≈øhould touch at any of the≈øe Northern places, e≈øpecially in the Chanel, and ≈øo Trade; and will ≈øend out Ships with fre≈øh men, and take out the Mariners that return, to prevent their trading for them≈øelves: but yet the extraordinary Charges of our men of War might be ≈øpared. 5. Such as are Rich, and weary of Trade, or love their ea≈øe, honour, or plea≈øure; may if we were under England, more ea≈øily remove thither, and be made liege ≈øubjects, and free Denizens of England by the Crown; or be naturalized by the Parliament; and ≈øo buy po≈ø≈øe≈øs, and inherit Lands and revenues at half the price here; and live upon their Rents as Country Gentlemen, in a cheap and plea≈øant Land, enjoying as great civil Liberty as any where in Chri≈øtendom, and al≈øo the freedom of their Religion. I have often thought this 20 years, whether it might not be better for England, to give this Liberty by Law to ≈øtrangers, e≈øpecially tho≈øe of the Reformed Religion, and of the≈øe Countries; and of which ≈øide the intere≈øt lay betwixt us for this: Now that England hath ≈øo many and great Plantations in the We≈øt Indies for their poorer people, now that money is ≈øo plentiful, now that this Common-wealth was ≈øo increa≈øed upon them, now that the Number of Merchants is every where ≈øo multiplied, and now that Trade is beaten ≈øo low, almo≈øt in all the known parts of the World. But this would be both a large, and unnece≈ø≈øary digre≈ø≈øion, and I am very ≈øen≈øible that I have been already too long in this Argument. Yet indu≈øtriou≈øly I confe≈øs, becau≈øe I fore≈øee, that many will diligently peru≈øe this, who perhaps will negligently pa≈øs by the re≈øt: and mine Oppo≈øites ≈øo much glorying herein, I thought be≈øt to give them full mea≈øure, and rather abound to curio≈øitie, than be deficient in ≈øatisfying the lea≈øt nicity; Trade being the Crown of that Kingdom and this Common wealth.

div.head: Sect. 8. Several other Arguments and enducements to incline us rather for England, briefly mentioned. With an inference from the whole preceding di≈øcour≈øe, that the friend≈øhip of England is to be prefered before that of France.

And thus I have done with this great Que≈øtion of the times. Sufficiently, I thinke, to ≈øatisfie any rational man; though nothing is ≈øufficient, nor will ≈øatisfie I know, ≈øuch as are either ≈øo re≈øolvedly prejudiced again≈øt the Engli≈øh or Princes intere≈øt that if they can but ruin them, they matter not though they ruin both them≈øelves and the Nation; or ≈øo partially pa≈ø≈øionate for the French, that they de≈øire them, though it be to their own de≈øtruction. That ≈øeeing England and We are of the ≈øame Religion; Both free people and affectionated to each other; Both imbarqued in the ≈øame Intere≈øt of Trade, though in different bottoms; It not only becomes us, but is our mutual concernment, that we take heed, we da≈øh not one another to pieces, but fairly and Chri≈øtianly comply with each other, for the ≈øafeguard of our Religion, pre≈øervation of the Prote≈øtant Intere≈øt, our own and others al≈øo Liberties, and the ju≈øt and equitable cour≈øe of Commerce; that ≈øo each Nation may happily enjoy their Religion, Liberty, E≈øtates, and Trade, with Gods ble≈ø≈øing on them all.

div.head: Sect. 9. That we are not yet come to that extremity, but we may ≈øtill remain a Republick: in regard of our own ≈øtrength, and our neighbours intere≈øt, Englands e≈øpecially, that they had better lo≈øe Scotland or Ireland, than let the French have the≈øe Provinces. div.p:
WE have hitherto di≈øcour≈øed upon the ≈øuppo≈øal of inability to defend our ≈øelves; becau≈øe it becomes wi≈øe men always, to ≈øuppo≈øe the wor≈øt condition that may probably befall them; with the con≈øequences thereof; and accordingly to make provi≈øion, and in regard of the endle≈øs curio≈øity of mens minds, which are always re≈øtle≈øs under mi≈øeries, and ≈øtill inqui≈øitive after futurities. Fir≈øt lets take a view of our own ≈øtrength, and ≈øee what grounds of encouragement, that will yield us. Which though ≈øufficiently known to many, yet not ≈øo well to the multitude. Now the ≈øtrength of a Nation con≈øi≈øts e≈øpecially in the≈øe things following, which I ≈øhall briefly recite, and accommodate to our own Country.

1. The great ≈øtrength of a people con≈øi≈øts in the ≈øituation of their Country.
Now concerning this both in the general,Sect. 7. and this Land in particular, I have already ≈øpoken ≈øufficiently for my purpo≈øe; and ≈øhewn that all the≈øe Maritime Provinces, are either I≈ølands or Penin≈øular, and very defen≈øible thereby; and al≈øo upon extremity liable to inundation, either from the Sea, or Rivers that ≈øurround them, or both.

2. In the Artificial Fortification of particular places; Cities, Ca≈øtles, Forts, Pa≈ø≈øes, &c. 3. In means of defence. As ≈øhipping for tho≈øe Nations or Cities that lie upon the Sea, or great navigable Rivers, and Lakes, as the≈øe Provinces do, to defend their Coa≈øts from inva≈øion. 4. In men; in regard of their Number, Courage, Skill, and Unanimity.

As to our Numbers, they are abundantly ≈øufficient for our defence. The Intere≈øt of Holland c. 8. from particulars, reckons the ≈øum of that Province alone 2400000. But if there be ≈øo many in them all, it is enow. Ju≈øt how many is impo≈ø≈øible to ≈øay, or near how many in ≈øuch a multitude is very difficult to gue≈øs, and harder with us than any other people, I think, in the World; in regard of the uncertainty of Seamen, the Number of Strangers and Travellers in peaceable times, and the diver≈øity of Religions, Jews, Papi≈øts, Anabapti≈øts, &c. which bapti≈øe not their Children with us. But I know the Number of our men mu≈øt needs be great; by the great Number of our Cities, the≈øe ≈øeveral Provinces being as it were nothing but Ne≈øts of Cities, ≈øo many being no where to be found in ≈øo ≈ømall a circumference in any parts of the habitable World; by their largene≈øs and multitude of hou≈øes, which imply the Inhabitants to be many; by the greatne≈øs of their Trade, which is the lure that draws multitudes to them; and by the known Chri≈øtnings and burials of tho≈øe only of the Reformed Religion.

As to our courage, which at pre≈øent ≈øuffers an eclip≈øe, there is more to be ≈øaid then the World is aware of. And indeed I wonder none of our Hi≈øtory Profe≈ø≈øors, have given other Nations ≈øome ≈øatisfaction herein. I have not been without ≈øome thoughts of doing it my ≈øelf, having been a diligent ob≈øerver how things have gone, but I want Authentick materials for ≈øuch a work. both ancient and modern of their valour, our of ≈øuch Writers as give the Characters of Nations, Republicks, Geographers, and e≈øpecially Hi≈øtorians Dion, Cae≈øar, Tacitus, Suetonius, Florus, Oro≈øius, &c. of old, the famous Italians, Guicciardine, Bentivoglio and Strada, with Spani≈øh, French, Engli≈øh and the neighbouring Nations, even ≈øo many and ≈øuch as are ≈øufficient either to ≈øhame, or to inflame the verie≈øt cowards, one ≈øhould think, of the world into courage. But this would be too large to in≈øert here, and may po≈ø≈øibly de done in another dre≈øs hereafter. Nor is the ≈øucce≈øs of France again≈øt us ≈øuch a wonder, as many make it, as I have formerly ≈øhewn.Sect. 7. I will at pre≈øent only add, that which is proper for this place, and that is that the French Armies were not only ≈øo numerous, but al≈øo trained up in the School of Mars, and ours for the mo≈øt part raw and unexperienced in War. And I doubt not, but through Gods ble≈ø≈øing, in a little time if the Wars continue, our Belgick Lion, will not be found ≈øuch a tame Lamb, and ≈øo ea≈øily torn in pieces, as our enemies may hope, and others po≈ø≈øibly may imagin.

As for our skill ≈øuperadded to courage, there is no want, for the manner of defence we are to make. For be≈øides our able Commanders and Souldiers to defend the Po≈øts, and Pa≈ø≈øes abroad, all our Cities abound with Seamen, and ≈øuch as are skil'd to traver≈øe their Ordnance, and de≈øperate for ≈øallies, if need ≈øhould require.

Our unanimity, I confe≈øs, is that I mo≈øt fear: and that when our Cities are threatned with danger, the Citizens ≈øhould grow mutinous, and fall together by the ears, and ≈øo let in their enemies to part the fray. 5. In money and food to maintain their men. And in neither of the≈øe, through Gods mercy, is there any want among≈øt us: If we will lay out our ≈øelves, as we ought, for the publick. Ait≈øma's Liewe reckons the publick incoms of Holland alone A. 1643. at eleven Millions of our money, which is eleven hundred thou≈øand pounds Sterling: we calling every ten thou≈øand pound Sterling a tun of gold, and ever hundred thou≈øand a million i. e. of gilders. Now what can be added for the ≈øufficient defence of any Nation, to the particulars mentioned, I cannot imagin; and if my enumeration be in≈øufficient, I wi≈øh any wi≈øe man would ≈øhew wherein, and then I ≈øhall thank them. And therefore let us take courage to our ≈øelves, and not be frighted with vain fears; or ≈øcared with any vanting bravadoes; like that great Rhodomontadoe of the grand Turk, who when he heard of the long War ≈øuch a great Prince as Spain, made about this ≈ømall Country; ≈øaid, that before he would have kept ≈øuch a pottering, about a few petty Provinces, he would have taken them, and hurled them into the Sea at once: though his ≈øucce≈ø≈øor kept no ≈ømall pottering about the ≈øingle City of Candia many years together; to which ≈øome of our Cities, all things con≈øidered, ≈øeem not much inferior for ≈øtrength: although I well know what a difference there is, betwixt the defence of one City alone without a Country, and many at once contained therein.

But though this internal ≈øtrength be ≈øo con≈øiderable, and with us of greate≈øt con≈øequence; yet this is not all; we have al≈øo an external and accidental ≈øtrength, by the Intere≈øt of our Neighbours. would ≈øoon, if let alone, de≈øtroy and devour all before them.

Now if we look about us, and ≈øee among≈øt whom our Land lies, and well con≈øider their intere≈øt; this will be very apparent in our ≈øelves, notwith≈øtanding this War that is made again≈øt us, that we are not devoted by any to de≈øtruction, but only the French, as I ≈øhall ≈øhew hereafter.

For Spain our next Neighbours on one hand, in the re≈øt of the Provinces, they know this ≈øo well, and are ≈øo ≈øen≈øible of their intere≈øt herein; that they not only a≈ø≈øi≈øt us what they can; but I dare ≈øay were it not for England, would rather break with France than ≈øee us endangered. For the Empire above us, they al≈øo are frighted with our fears; and if the Princes thereof had money to their might, would willingly, I doubt not, a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Emperor: le≈øt the Lillies of France ≈øhould mount above the Roman Eagle. In the year 15 ‚Ä¢ 4. when the States upon the death of Prince William, were a looking towards France for Protection, the Princes of the Empire ≈øent Malroy to admoni≈øh them, ut √† con≈øilio Gallici patrocinii implorandi de≈øi≈øterent, alioqui fore, ut Germani Principes tantam domui Au≈øtriacae & origine & foedere arctis adeo cum Imperio vinculis conjunctae factam injuriam non negligant, as Thuanus tells us, l. 80. And if they were then jealous of France, what ≈øhall we think they are now? And France to be ≈øure will never ≈øee us entirely Engli≈øh: for ≈øo he knows, he ≈øhould never be able, to ballance Englands power at Sea; which he doubtle≈øs both hopes and aims at, by the acce≈ø≈øion of ≈øtrength from the≈øe Netherlands.

Nor England ≈øuffer us, if they can hinder it, to be wholly French; for this they know would clearly tend, in a little time to their de≈øtruction. This very Rea≈øon of State moved Q. Elizabeth at fir≈øt to ≈øupport us again≈øt Spain, rather than to have us fall into the Arms of France, by their becoming our Protectors. L. 80. And

But that is not ≈øo clear to me, nor will be ≈øo I think to others, who rightly con≈øider the circum≈øtances of tho≈øe times; for we mu≈øt not judge by the following, wherein this Common-wealth grew up beyond all expectation, under ≈øuch Wars, as many feared would have been our de≈øtruction. Nor can any one think, that England is not ≈øen≈øible, of the danger they are in, if we be under France, that either con≈øiders the Rea≈øons of State, or obe≈øerved that which was obvious to every eye: and that is how the Engli≈øh was ≈øtartled at the progre≈øs of France. And no wonder, if we con≈øider the Con≈øequences thereof for England, which are ≈øo great that they had better lo≈øe either Scotland, or Ireland. And if any Engli≈øh think I overla≈øh, I ≈øhall de≈øire them fir≈øt carefully to compute the≈øe ≈øeveral particulars, and then cen≈øure.

5. The hazard they run of being baffled and beat out of their Trade by ≈øuch a War. It is true, this is not ≈øo ea≈øie as many of the Dutch imagine, as I have already proved; nor yet ≈øo difficult, much le≈øs impo≈ø≈øible, as perhaps ≈øome of the Engli≈øh may fancy.

div.p: I ≈øhall not now ≈øtand to draw the≈øe out of their clo≈øe order into an open, yet if any of the Engli≈øh think me weak in this, I have a Re≈øerve, which, I think, will ≈øufficiently ≈øecure me from being routed.
It will be ≈øaid to me why then ≈øhould England commence this War.

Truly let me ≈øay it freely, for I know it, that the ≈øcale of War very hardly ca≈øt that of peace, and the difference was ≈øo ≈ømall, that it came upon two or three grains only. I have weighed this as exactly as I po≈ø≈øibly could: fir≈øt di≈øtingui≈øhing pretexts from real cau≈øes, and then di≈øtinctly con≈øidering the≈øe one by one. There were the≈øe 5 variou≈øly di≈øcour≈øed of. His Maje≈øties de≈øigning to introduce the Popi≈øh Religion; to alter the government of tho≈øe Kingdoms; to revenge him≈øelf upon us, to advance the Prince of Orange; and the Intere≈øt of the Kingdom of England.

For the two fir≈øt which made the loude≈øt noi≈øe in ≈øome mens mouths, I ≈øoon found them frivolous; and only calumnies ca≈øt out by his enemies at home and abroad, to make the King odious, and his People jealous. As to that of changing Religion I have formerly ≈øhewn, and I think ≈øufficiently, that he neither will, nor can if he would effect it.

As for the 2d. I con≈øidered the Kings years, as being pa≈øt any ≈øuch youthful and vain ambition; his being de≈øtitute of a Child that can challenge the Crown; his former mi≈øeries and ≈øufferings by War; and his wi≈ødom too great, to ≈øet upon a de≈øign, ≈øo wholly impracticable, e≈øpecially in England and Scotland. For by the con≈øtitution of his Kingdoms, though he have the Militis for the execution of the Laws; authority without power, being a vain ≈øcare crow, and in≈øufficient to ≈øuppre≈øs the audacious exorbitances of the multitude: yet the people have the pur≈øe to ballance that power, and whence then would he pay his Armies? Nor let any one ≈øtop me with ≈øaying, the Long Parliament conte≈øted with his Father for the Militia; for that was only temporary, they challenging it only for that time of the danger they apprehended in the Kingdom, and not as their con≈øtant right, and not belonging to the Crown; as may be ≈øeen by tho≈øe, who will rightly read their Declarations, which they publi≈øhed to the world concerning that War, collected and printed together by Husbands at London, 1642. And be≈øides this, a Parliament in being though not ≈øitting, which hath
≈øome kind of radical power; though not to be exerted, but when legally congregated. But ≈øuppo≈øe them di≈ø≈øolved, it being in the Kings power, to do it at his plea≈øure; yet hath he not the City of London on his back, and both Kingdoms about him to oppo≈øe him? e≈øpecially con≈øidering that the jealou≈øie of Popery would be taken into the quarrel. And what Mini≈øters of State dur≈øt ≈øugge≈øt ≈øuch de≈øigns? they know well the maxim of the Commons and their practice (as the great means of pre≈øerving their freedom) is to ruine ≈øuch as would infringe their Liberty. And that they are ≈øo jealous of, and zealous for their rights herein, that ≈øome of them ≈øtill have the courage, and re≈øolution to venture their own heads, to break the necks of ≈øuch men and ≈øuch defigns, as would prejudice their Priviledges. I have ob≈øerved in the Hi≈øtories of former times, and in my own time al≈øo, that there were ≈øeldom any of the noble≈øt Stags of State, how much ≈øoever imparked in the Kings favour, and how ≈øtrongly ≈øoever impaled with power; but if the Commons of England ≈øingled him out and ≈øet upon him, though he might hold them at an abay for ≈øome time, yet they ≈øtill hunted him down at la≈øt. And for the King to think of making him≈øelf ab≈øolute, and govern only by an Army (like the French Kings) by an Army of French men; is ≈øo ridiculous, that I thought it not worthy of con≈øideration. Can any man in his wits, imagine his Maje≈øty of England ≈øo ≈øen≈øele≈øs, as to give his Crown and Kingdoms to the French King? For that is all one with this in effect.

As for that of Revenge, either for Chattam, or the affronts mentioned in his Declaration of this War, or both: I con≈øidered his Temper, which hath ≈øo much Clemency, that it rather inclines him to lenity than cruelty and revenge. As is abundantly apparent, not only by pa≈ø≈øing, but even forcing (as I know he did, again≈øt ≈øome adicted to the latter extreme) the Act of Indemnity or Oblivion, for tho≈øe many and great injuries, he had ≈øuffered from his Subjects. And his government ≈øince, in conniving at the violation of ≈øuch Laws, as are thought ≈øevere in matters of Religion, and indulging liberty therein: which hath made ≈øome, that have ≈øufficiently heretofore cried up Parliaments, now run into the other extreme and cry them down as fa≈øt; and in≈øtead of the Parliaments formerly, now magnifie the Kings favour and Clemency. And yet Kings and Princes are men, and men ≈øubject to like pa≈ø≈øions with others, liable to ≈øugge≈øtions from tho≈øe about them, and tender of their honour as the apple of their eye. And therefore I will grant this might come in con≈øideration, but not ≈øo much, I dare ≈øay, as alone to make a War.

For the Prince of Orange, there was not only near Relation and Affection, but Intere≈øt al≈øo to be con≈øidered. For the Love≈øteyns party having been ≈øo cro≈øs to England upon his account, and the corre≈øpondent friend≈øhip between us ≈øo uncertain, without his Head≈øhip; I verily believe, that if what is now done therein, had been done timou≈øly, it had wholly prevented this unhappy War. Yea be≈øides the extraordinary affection which
the people have for the Prince, our very Bores had this Policy, and were more than ordinary zealous for his promotion, as the be≈øt means to procure their peace.
As to the further intere≈øt of the Kingdom of England, in regard of their Trade, and Naval expences, I have expre≈ø≈øed my thoughts before in the Preface.

It is true, this War was always intricate, and hath proved a Game at Hazard for England, beyond not only theirs, I believe, but all the worlds expectation. But yet if it be ≈øtill notwith≈øtanding cautiou≈øly played, as they may, and ≈øo far as I can po≈ø≈øibly di≈øcern, mean to play it; they can many ways come to ≈øave their ≈øtakes, at the lea≈øt, if not to win more than we imagine by the War: and was far fairer at fir≈øt than France for winning by the game in all humane appearance, as I could manife≈øt by many Arguments. But becau≈øe that concerns them two only, and us not at all further than our ≈øufferings, I ≈øhall wave them (at lea≈øt for the pre≈øent) and proceed. For I will not hearken to the curious enquiries of tho≈øe who would here be asking, how I think England will play their game? for that let them look to it whom it concerns on all ≈øides, as doubtle≈øs they will; for me to expre≈øs my private thoughts, might do more hurt than good, which is the only thing I aim at: and what I think the i≈ø≈øue will be, I ≈øhall declare hereafter in my Conjectures.
But here it will be asked, ≈øeeing it is Englands intere≈øt that we fall not into the hands of France, and that the Prince is now promoted, will they not make peace with us this Winter?

I mu≈øt needs ≈øay, I fear they will not, except we ≈øhould give them ≈øuch terms, as I ≈øee we ≈øhall not; we thinking our condition far better, and they thinking it far wor≈øe, than really it is. For the cau≈øe of this, as of mo≈øt Wars, is complex, as I have ≈øhewn; ≈øo that though two of tho≈øe I a≈ø≈øigned may be pa≈øt, yet the 3d of the Kingdoms intere≈øt, not. They are already too far ingaged in the War, and with France. The Kings Honour is at the ≈øtake, and the Kingdoms expectation of another i≈ø≈øae than the la≈øt War. And be≈øides all the≈øe, how can any wi≈øe man imagine, now that they are engaged with France, and have an advantage again≈øt us, as well as a Hazard from France; that if they know how to ≈øecure them≈øelves again≈øt the latter (as I ≈øuppo≈øe they do) they will let go the former? For we mu≈øt needs think they will be at a certainty on one ≈øide or the other; and not part with France's friend≈øhip, till they be ≈øure of our ≈øatisfaction. What it is they demand, or how rightly, is not now our de≈øign to di≈øcour≈øe, but only matter of Intere≈øt all along. And yet I can ea≈øily fore≈øee that the danger of our becoming French, will be a ≈øingular advantage to us, as an inducement to them, for a more ea≈øie compliance with us. But at pre≈øent I ≈øee no probability of Peace, but that they will go through with the War: or continue it ≈øo long, till they have tryed their utmo≈øt to obtain their ends.

I know there are many wi≈øe men among≈øt us, that think the King cannot
carry on this War: as there was that thought he could not begin it. The former they find them≈øelves deceived in, and will be ≈øo in the latter al≈øo. I have di≈øcour≈øed this with ≈øeveral in Government, who argue that the King hath not money of him≈øelf to go through with the War, and that he will not convene the Parliament, or if he do they will not ≈øupply him. For if we rightly con≈øider their defign, the Parliament mu≈øt meet, and the repre≈øentation that will be made thereof, and the con≈øtitution of the Parliament, they will grant him ≈øupplies; though perhaps not with that facility, that they did it with in the former War. And therefore let us neither flatter nor deceive our ≈øelves with vain hopes herein; but rather ≈øeek timely to accommodate differences, before their preparations in the Spring; for I fear the longer we delay, and the wor≈øe it will be with us.

div.head: Sect. 10. Compliance with England the only means of the Commonwealths continuation.
div.p: HAving thus declared the condition that we are in, and that there is no probability of peace; we come now to ≈øhew the con≈øequences thereof; and what is to be done by us, to pre≈øerve our ≈øelves from ruine and de≈øtruction. And here to my under≈øtanding one of the≈øe three things mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily follow: That we mu≈øt either continue the War again≈øt them both; or comply with them both; or with one of them alone if po≈ø≈øibly we can. We ≈øhall fir≈øt declare our thoughts concerning the≈øe briefly, and then ≈øhew with which we both may and mu≈øt comply.

1. Then whether we ≈øhould continue the War again≈øt them both. And herein would we do, as we might and ≈øhould; it may be this were better, than to comply with either of them, e≈øpecially if they will impo≈øe upon us unrea≈øonable conditions, and much better than to comply with them both. We have ≈øtrength enough, through Gods ble≈ø≈øing, to with≈øtand them (as I have already manife≈øted) if we have but courage, and unanimity; and the former of the≈øe will be got by degrees, as I have ≈øaid, and our own intere≈øt, and pre≈øervation ≈øhould per≈øwade us into the latter. But truly let me ≈øay it freely, I ≈øee ≈øuch a wearine≈øs in many of the War; ≈øuch an unwillingne≈øs to lay out our ≈øelves, as our Ance≈øtors did formerly, for the good of the publick; ≈øuch a ≈øelfi≈øh temper, every one ≈øeeking to pre≈øerve his particular intere≈øt, and neglecting the good of the Community; and ≈øuch a lothne≈øs to adventure our lives and e≈øtates in a War; that I ≈øee little probability of pre≈øerving our ≈øelves, and much le≈øs of prevalency again≈øt our Enemies. So that if this War continue I fear the≈øe Provinces will become a prey to them both. For though neither France will ≈øuffer England, nor England France to have them all, as I have ≈øhewn; yet they will part and ≈øhare them betwixt them, except we prevent it by a compliance.
And what a mi≈øerable condition we ≈øhall then be in, even wor≈øe than if we were under either of them, I have formerly declared. Seeing then we are ≈øo degenerate, and become like I≈ø≈øachar, which his Father ≈øtiles a Strong A≈øs, and ≈øays of him, that He ≈øaw that re≈øt was good, Gen. 49.14, 15. and the land that it was plea≈øant; and bowed his ≈øhoulder to bear, and became a ≈øervant unto tribute: we mu≈øt either take courage and be unanimous, valiantly fighting it out with our enemies; or for the pre≈øent be contented with this character and condition. Will we then fight for our Religion, Liberty, Country, Families, E≈øtates, Trade? or will we not? If the former, let me encourage all in the words of Joab that great General and brave Souldier wherewith he encouraged the I≈øraelites, when he had his enemies before and behind him, Be of good courage, and let us play the men for our people and for the Cities of our God: and the Lord do that which ≈øeemeth him good. 2 Sam. 10.12. But if the re≈øt be ≈øo good, and the Land ≈øo plea≈øant to us, that we will rather how our ≈øhoulders, and become ≈øervants, than ≈øhew our faces in the field to fight with our enemies, let us ≈øee what Ma≈øter we ≈øhould chu≈øe, and agree with him upon the be≈øt terms we can.

2. Therefore, ≈øhall we comply with both our enemies? ≈øurely if rea≈øon, and what we can give, will ≈øatisfie them; every wi≈øe man will ≈øay Yes, that we may enjoy the many ble≈ø≈øings God hath given us in peace. But if they will have ≈øuch Cities, ≈øuch va≈øt ≈øums of money, and ≈øuch Conditions, as we cannot give them, except we be ruined thereby; who will not ≈øay, No. We mu≈øt therefore con≈øider if there be no other way practicable, to ≈øave our ≈øelves, from the devouring Sword of our Enemies.

3. There is no way therefore left us, but to comply with one of our Enemies, if we can po≈ø≈øibly; that ≈øo we may ballance the others power, and either compel him to a peace, or be enabled to continue the War. If any one know any other way, I heartily wi≈øh he would ≈øhew it, as I think he is bound to do one way or other; for every one ought to contribute his be≈øt a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, even by the principles of ≈øelf-pre≈øervation. Eccle≈ø. 9.15, 16. And Solomon tells us, There was a poor wi≈øe man, who by his wi≈ødom delivered the City, though no man remembred him, and infers thence, that wi≈ødom is better than ≈øtrength, though the poor mans wi≈ødom is de≈øpi≈øed, and his words are not heard. But I believe mo≈øt will grant the way is good, but impracticable, in regard of the League betwixt the two Crowns, and that they will not treat a≈øunder, &c. Well then, let us proceed to con≈øider the≈øe things a little, and ≈øee whether we cannot level the≈øe mountains of difficulties that are before us, and make our way become plain and pa≈ø≈øable.

1. With which of the≈øe our Enemies we ≈øhould chu≈øe to comply, I think I have made ≈øufficiently apparent; in ≈øhewing it our Intere≈øt rather to be under England than France, and to have peace and corre≈øpondent friend≈øhip for our Sea-traffick, with the former rather than with the latter, if we
cannot have it from them both. And I am ≈øure this was the wi≈ødom of our Ance≈øtors, who in their low condition A.D. 1575. deliberating into who≈øe Protection they ≈øhould give them≈øelves over, fir≈øt declared the Empire, and the competition coming between the Crowns of England and France prefer'd the former upon many and weighty con≈øiderations,Cambden Annales Eli≈øabethae A. 1575. Thuanus l. 60. Ca≈øus 20. relared by their Hi≈øtorians; and very many of our own, which are ≈øo well known I need not mention them; and Boxhornius the Author of the Di≈øqui≈øitiones Politicae. The civil Wars of France; the inveterate fend betwixt French and Dutch, tho≈øe e≈øpecially that live upon the Confines of both Countries; the hard yoke of the French Government; the levity of that Nation; its liablne≈øs to be invaded by the Spani≈øh; the incommodiou≈øne≈øs of their Ports for our Ships and Navigation; made them aver≈øe to France. And on the contrary, The reformed Religion of the Engli≈øh, their greater likene≈øs with us in genious and language, the nearne≈øs of the Country; the multitude of their Ports; their commodiou≈øne≈øs for our Commerce; the multiplicity of the Engli≈øh Manifactures and Commodities; the Country not ea≈øily invaded; ≈øtrong and potent by Sea and Land; not frequently imbroyled in civil Wars; a free People; the Government temperate, and not burthen≈øom with exactions; and the Intere≈øt of the Engli≈øh Nation, which if the≈øe Countries were conquered, would ≈øearce be able to re≈øi≈øt the Conqueror; clearly enclined them for England. You ≈øee then that rea≈øons of State, direct us to the ≈øame choice, which our Ance≈øtors heretofore wi≈øely made.

2. Seeing then we mu≈øt chu≈øe England, not only for the Common Intere≈øt of the Prote≈øtant Religion, but for our own greate≈øt both religious, and civil concernments. We ≈øhall now remove tho≈øe ob≈øtructions that ≈øeem to block up our way to Compliance.
It is objected that the two Crowns are in a League, that neither will treat without the other, and how can we then comply with England alone?

I confe≈øs if all State≈ømen were Ari≈øtides's,Plutarch. in vita Ari≈øtid. the Argument might be ≈øtrong.
