But we ≈øee it is far otherwi≈øe now in the World;Plutarch. l. 4. Sympo≈ø. Cicer. 3. Offic. & 1. de Leg. and that the Peripateticks doctrine that hone≈øtum and utile are really di≈øtingui≈øhed, is every where prevalent, and no where more, than among≈øt Politicians; which hath occa≈øioned that known ≈øaying, that all States are Athei≈øts. I do not approve any, and much le≈øs ≈øo high uncharitablene≈øs; but this I will ≈øay, that as the world goes now, all States mu≈øt be con≈øidered as Game≈øters. And what if I ≈øhould ≈øay, that neither of the Courts are ≈øo ≈øtrait laced in their Con≈øciences, but were they a≈ø≈øured from us of ≈øuch conditions as they require, they would let the other go and get theirs as they could? Nay what if I ≈øhould ≈øay, there may be none iniquity in this? If I ≈øhould, I think I can prove it, for if in mutual covenants, either ≈øide do that, which is a breach; it is folly
to think, that the innocent ≈øhould be bound, and the peccant party free, which they may know, though others do not, as it is clear in the ≈øtronge≈øt covenant, that is in the World, I mean that of wedlock. I do not ≈øay that this is ≈øo betwixt them, but I ≈øay it may be ≈øo though we do not know it, ≈øo that either of them in ≈øuch ca≈øe, may conclude with us. And I am ≈øure it is no di≈øhone≈øty on our part.
But it will here be ≈øaid, they will not.

Do not tell me that, I know they either of them will. And if any one asks me, how? and if I be of their Cabinet Council? I ≈øhall only ≈ømile, perceiving they do not know me. I am far from that, or having ever to do with Kings or States in that kind, or pragmatically trinketing with State affairs, it being a Rule which I live by, never to ask great men mercy. Common favour and ju≈øtice I de≈øire of men, but mercy only of my God. And yet I know this very well, and I will tell you how, and that is from their Intere≈øt; which is the compa≈øs, by which all States-men ≈øteer their cour≈øe, and may be di≈øcerned by a skilful pa≈ø≈øenger, although he ≈øit not at the helm. If any man be ≈øo ignorant of the affairs of the World, as to think that States-men trouble their heads with the Scool-mens quiddities, and haeccieties, or their con≈øciences with Ca≈øui≈øticall nicities, as a late German Divine that puts the ca≈øe, whether we ≈øhould pray Vader on≈øe, or On≈øe Vader, and learnedly concludes that cu≈øtom mu≈øt carry it; let him enjoy his opinion, it is very charitable, and can do no hurt. But yet I may ≈øay, that for above 20 years I have ob≈øerved, that the cu≈øtom of the World carries it with them, and have known few, I had almo≈øt ≈øaid none, of the ≈øtricte≈øt Sect of the Phari≈øees; though I have ≈øome, and my charity obliges me to hope there are many, that ≈øeriou≈øly mind the weightier things of the Law, ju≈øtice, righteou≈ønes, temperance, and the World to come.

Now that this is the Intere≈øt of both the Kings, rather to deal with us apart, than jointly, as well as ours, I could many ways make apparent. But ≈øeeing it is our intere≈øt to chu≈øe England we ≈øhall prove only that it is theirs to comply with us; omitting that of France, as ≈øuperfluous to our purpo≈øe.

1. They know they cannot wholly conquer us them≈øelves. Not only in regard of our own ≈øtrength, of which I haven ≈øpoken before, but the French, which are in the Country already, and if they were not, would never permit it, as I have formerly ≈øhown ≈øufficiently. Nay I dare ≈øay, they never de≈øigned any ≈øuch thing, becau≈øe they know it is impracticable: that being always true of the Greeks, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ or things impo≈ø≈øible come not into con≈øideration. I doubt not but they both intend and hope to have their ≈øhare, what ever it is that is agreed upon between the two Crowns, in ca≈øe of Conque≈øt; but that they ≈øhould have the whole, could never ≈øo much as be dreamt of by them.

2. They know al≈øo that it is their intere≈øt, never to ≈øuffer France have all, no nor any of the≈øe Maritime Provinces. If he have ≈øome of the ≈øuperior,
that is the utmo≈øt their intere≈øt can permit. Nay indeed he is nearer the≈øe inferior, than that will allow, if they could help it, but that's now pa≈øt. What va≈øt di≈øadvantage it will be to the Engli≈øh, to let France have footing upon our Coa≈øts, and ≈øo come to cope with them at Sea, I have formerly ≈øhown: and I know they are very ≈øen≈øible of it; and therefore may well infer a willingne≈øs on their parts to a compliance.

3. The Prince of Orange his intere≈øt being al≈øo theirs, cannot but ≈øway ≈øomething with them. For if it had been Gods will, tho≈øe Kingdoms had continued in peace, and the ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of the Royal reign uninterrupted there, and the Orange family continued alive and in power here, I per≈øwade my ≈øelf we ≈øhould never have warred with one another; ≈øo I doubt not, if it plea≈øe God to pre≈øerve his Highne≈øs, that they may confide more in our friend≈øhip, than they could formerly, he will be a happy In≈øtrument of a better under≈øtanding between the Nations, when the≈øe unhappy quarrels come once to be compo≈øed; becau≈øe this is their intere≈øt as well as ours, and it is intere≈øt that rules and reigns in the World.
And thus I have ≈øhewn you that we may, I ≈øhall now ≈øhew briefly that we mu≈øt comply with them, or without a miracle of mercy we are ruined.

1. Becau≈øe if the War continues, and we be too weak to make ≈øtrong re≈øi≈øtance, ≈øo that our enemies prevail; they will ≈øhare the Country betwixt them, and then we fall into the wor≈øt condition, that can po≈ø≈øibly befal us. It is true, I fore≈øee that ≈øeveral particular Per≈øons may ≈øave them≈øelves and their e≈øtates, by friends on the one ≈øide or the other; but I ≈øpeak of the community; and it is well if the hopes many have of that, make them not more negligent for this. There are two famous Republicks in Italy, Venice and Genoa; and what is the cau≈øe of the formers flouri≈øhing ≈øo much more than the latter, which was anciently both their better and their Ma≈øter? but this, that the Venetians are more intent upon the Publick, and the Genoe≈øe upon their private concernments: whereby they become obnoxious not only to many factions among them≈øelves, but al≈øo to oppre≈ø≈øions from their Neighbours. I could ≈øay more herein of our ≈øelves, than I ≈øhall at pre≈øent, in regard it might create more jealou≈øies (which are already too many) of tho≈øe that are, or at lea≈øt have been, in Government among≈øt us. But though I will accu≈øe none, yet I mu≈øt needs ≈øay, that I a≈øcribe a great part of our pre≈øent mi≈øeries to this Genoan practice; and heartily wi≈øh, this prove not fatal to us at la≈øt.

2. Becau≈øe if we be not ≈øen≈øele≈øs we may clearly ≈øee, that France's de≈øign is ab≈øolutely to conquer us: whereas England ≈øeeks only (to u≈øe their expre≈ø≈øion) their own ≈øecurity. And therefore in my Logick the inference is plain, that we had better part with ≈øomething, than lo≈øe all, as we are like to do, if we come not to a compliance with England. To make the≈øe apparent to any wi≈øe man, would be the lighting a Torch to the Sun. Although I know the quite contrary is ca≈øt out among us by the friends of France, who would per≈øwade us, that the French ≈øeek only to humble
us, and the Engli≈øh to conquer us. But we know the minding of men, is but ≈øhooting at random, and that he that means to come near the truth, mu≈øt have his eye upon the mark of intere≈øt, which cannot lye, as men do frequently for it. If any be ≈øo fooli≈øh, as to be enchanted with ≈øuch Syrens ≈øongs, as are daily ≈øung among≈øt us; and have more regard to publick news, than the intere≈øt of Nations; they may go on, I cannot hinder them: but let me tell them, that I fear they will find at la≈øt, the Poets fiction a real truth; and if they ≈øtear their own cour≈øe, meet with the Seamens fate in the Fable, be ≈øung a ≈øleep for a time, that ≈øo they may be afterwards, with greater facility drowned and devoured.

3. Becau≈øe there is no other way or humane means le≈øt us (≈øo far as I can di≈øcern) of the Common-wealths continuation. And this is the conclu≈øion that follows clearly from the premi≈øes. For if we be unable to with≈øtand them both, or ≈øatisfie them both, we mu≈øt either break their confederacy, and have the help of one of them, or the Republick will be ruined.
It will here be demanded, ≈øeeing it is both Englands intere≈øt and our own to accord, why do we not then come to a compliance.

I will tell you why. Becau≈øe we judge our Condition better, and they judge it wor≈øe, than really it is; and therefore ≈øtand upon greater terms, than we will give them. We think things will go better with us in time, and they think they will grow wor≈øe. We flatter our ≈øelves with vain hopes, and rely upon Brandenburgs A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, Spains breaking with our enemies, the Parliament of Englands not ≈øupplying that King to carry on the War, and the like, when they know the quite contrary in all humane appearance. ‚Ä¢ or perhaps we are afraid to irritate France, if we ≈øhould make overtures to England; and England will not give ≈øuch an umbrage of jealou≈øie to France, as to tamper with us, except they be fir≈øt a≈ø≈øured from us of ≈øatisfaction. But cannot the effecting this be put into the hands of his Highne≈øs and a few others as it was lately, to be privately tran≈øacted by them? Here then it is that the ≈øhooe pinches, We are a popular State, the people ≈øtill think, till an enemy comes, they can defend them≈øelves, and therefore our Governors dare not adventure to tender England ≈øuch ≈øati≈øfaction, as (for ought I ≈øee) they will have; le≈øt they either ≈øhould not be able to perform it, or if they do, ≈øhould lo≈øe them≈øelves with the people. And therefore I fore≈øee, the War will be continued, till we be reduced to that condition, that we ≈øhall be nece≈ø≈øitated to give them both their demands, by publick tran≈øaction, or at lea≈øt that way break with one of them. And on this foundation, I ≈øhall now proceed, to gue≈øs at that which I think is mo≈øt likely to befal us.

div.head: Sect 11 Conjectures of future affairs. The motions of the en≈øuing summer likely to be quick and great. As to this Repulick, probably England may get a Bridle to curb us, France the sadle to ride us, Colen a ≈øupernumerary girth, Mun≈øter a bo≈øs of the Crupper. Our condition deplored and con≈øolated. A caution for England, and the Orange family. The Authors fears of what will at la≈øt befal us. The Spani≈øh Netherlands a dying. The friend≈øhip of England and France ≈øick at heart, and cannot live long. That of Spain and England ≈øound at heart, and will recover.
div.p: ALthough I have ≈øometimes ≈øpent almo≈øt whole nights at gazing on the Stars, and could perhaps erect an A≈øtrological Scheme as well as another; yet I never u≈øed that way, nor never ≈øhall for gue≈ø≈øing at faturities; becau≈øe I know it is vain to think, we cam ≈øpell Gods providence, by their my≈øtical hieroglyphick. Yet let me ≈øay it without vanity, I do believe I have made as many conjectures, concerning Kingdoms, States and particular places, as any man of my quality in Europe: not by any enthu≈øia≈øtick ≈øpirit of prophecy, or by A≈øtrology from the Stars; but rea≈øons of State, their intere≈øt, and the fundamental maxims of their Government; ≈øometimes out of curio≈øity only, and ≈øometimes for other ends, but ≈øuch as are hone≈øt I a≈ø≈øure you, for none are either better or wor≈øe by it, but only my brothers and my ≈øelf. The rea≈øon why I adventure to do this publickly now, is that I may awaken us out of our ≈øecurity, and that we may look about us, and ≈øee if po≈ø≈øibly we can prevent tho≈øe things, which it is very probable are coming upon us. Only I de≈øire to do it mode≈øtly, as it becomes every Chri≈øtian; and neither on the one hand to pretend to that certainty, as if we were of Gods Council; no on the other hand to fall under Chri≈øts rebuke for not di≈øcerning the ≈øigns of the times, Matth. 16. which are both theological and political, but I am now only treating of the latter, and to that I ≈øhall confine my di≈øcour≈øe.

Now that we may be quickned to defend our ≈øelves, comply with England, and free the Spani≈øh Netherlands from their fears, and our ≈øelves from the neighbourhood of the French there, (this being one Rea≈øon of State, why we formerly made peace with Spain, le≈øt we ≈øhould be in continual danger of annoyance from France) and al≈øo render their maintaining their Conque≈øts among us more difficult, by their being kept unconnected with that Kingdom: I ≈øhall now proceed to the Conjectures I have made, not with an A≈øtrological confidence, but a Chri≈øtian allowance of divine providence, which ≈øtrangely alters times and ≈øea≈øons, puls down one and ≈øets up another, confounds the wi≈ødom of the wi≈øe, brings to nought the coun≈øels of Achitophels, and turns the great de≈øigns and preparations for War, into a happy compliance, and peace as he plea≈øes; and all in infinite wi≈ødom, though we cannot di≈øcern it, the knowledge of Gods
providence even when pa≈øt or pre≈øent, and much more when future, being to David, and therfore far more to us. Too Wonderfull for us, P≈øal. 139.
≈øo high that we cannot attaine unto it, and ≈øo deepe in the great waters, that the foot≈øteps thereof are not to be traced and knowne. So that we may well ≈øay, as of old,P≈øal. 77.
Dei ≈øapientia, & hominum ≈øtultitia regunt mundum. Fir≈øt then, if we awake out of our ≈øecurity, and looke up in the morning of the yeare, we mu≈øt needs conclude of foule weather the en≈øuing Summer, the skie is ≈øo red, that we may ea≈øily perceive it portends blood, and the lowe≈øt region is ≈øo lowring, that we may ea≈øily di≈øcerne that a tempe≈øtuous ≈øtorme is a gathering; except we be ≈øo be≈øotted, as the fooli≈øh Jewes of old, with ≈øecurity, that we cannot di≈øcerne, as Chri≈øt tells them, the ≈øignes of the times. Can all Europe allmo≈øt be arming, and we a ≈øleepe in the Bed of Security, dreaming of Peace? Be≈øides the incredible preparations of France, is not England, Sweadland, and all our Neighbors allmo≈øt up and at worke; and can we thinke they would be at that co≈øt for a Comedy of Peace? have we not all the rea≈øon in the World, to thinke it will be to us, a Tragedy of War? Let others enjoy their opinion, and not take the alarme, till they ≈øee Hanibal ad portas; for my part, I mu≈øt needs profes, I cannot, from what I ob≈øerve, but conclude, that the affaires of the en≈øuing Summer, are like to be great, and the motions thereof quick, and ≈øuch as will highly concerne us in the≈øe Countreys.
As to this Republick, which hath at this time the≈øe four declared Enimies, England, France, Colen, and Mun≈øter; I ≈øhall briefly ≈øpeake my thoughts, with reference to them all.

England probably will get, a bridle to curb us. I have ≈øhewne in the Preface, what they account the Intre≈øt of the Kingdome: We ≈øee notwith≈øtanding the Prince of Orange his promotion, they ≈øtill pur≈øue the War; and mu≈øt we not then conclude, that they ≈øeeke ≈øome thing further? Whether they will by Sea attacque our Coa≈øts, or by marching their Armie about over Land, is not for me to determine; much les what particular places below they may fall upon, or what ≈øucces they may have. Yet I conclude they will have ≈øome hanke or other upon our Navall power, one way or other, before they make Peace with us; otherwi≈øe they will continue the War the following Summer, to try their utmo≈øt to get, that which we will not give them.

France that is allready got into the Sadle, will there ≈øit and ride us; though we flatter our ≈øelves, we ≈øhall by one means or other, ≈øhake him out of it, and off our backs. Truly I cannot but wonder often times, to heare what vaine hopes men expres and there's no contradicting them; (allthough ≈øome times I cannot conteine my ≈øelfe from ≈ømiling, or ≈øhakeing my head) that France mu≈øt be content with one or two of our Cities which we can be≈øt ≈øpare, and with a confidence allmo≈øt as large, as if they was ready to run way, or re≈øolved to march out and quit tho≈øe Cities they have, at our plea≈øure. As if the French were ≈øuch ≈øooles, to be at that va≈øt expence, great paines, even the King him≈øelfe per≈øonally, and have
≈øuch advantage upon us, and quit the ≈øame for a thing of nothing? For my part, I am affraid they will rather get more, then lo≈øe that they have gotten already. And I know, their de≈øigne is, to get all at la≈øt. It is true, if we comply with England, and ≈øo ≈øtrengthen our ≈øelves by them and Spaine, we may thereby hope either to obteine better conditions by Treaty, or compel them thereunto by Force. But I am ≈øpeaking of the ≈øtate of the War, as now it ≈øtands.

Colen, that pretends to ≈øome of tho≈øe Cities which we held about the Rhyne, that are now in the power and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the French, may po≈ø≈øibly for his paines, and permi≈ø≈øion of their pa≈ø≈øage, &c. get ≈øome ≈øupernumerary girth, one place or other that may be of no great concernment to France, either for their de≈øignes upon us or the Empire, and mu≈øt be contented therewith. And perhaps for ≈øome time his Coun≈øellors may have their Pen≈øions continued from France.

Mun≈øter, that is mercinary and fights for Money, will get a bos off the crupper; French Lewis's made and minted of Dutch Ducats. For elective Princes, as Bi≈øhops, that are onely for life, ≈øeek more to enrich them≈øelves, then to enlarge their Territories, as tho≈øe doe that are hereditary.

And this is likely, ≈øo far as I can ≈øee, to prove our condition; except „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ appeare in the Tragedy, or God Almighty by ≈øome wonderfull providence, make a change in the Scene of this War. Which, I confe≈øs, is very deplorable, which way ≈øoever we look; and we are not ≈øo ≈øen≈øible of it now, as we ≈øhall be hereafter. I had thought here to have ≈øit downe a little with a lamentation, but I have been ≈øo large already, that I ≈øhall wholly wave it for the pre≈øent.

And yet it is a had wind that blows no good, we may make this advantage of our mi≈øeries, ≈øo long as we remain amid≈øt our enimies, when a Peace is once concluded; that we may hold them both fair to us, and ≈øo ≈øecure our ≈øelves a little more in quiet, then we perhaps think, by being ready to clo≈øe with either, to the great prejudice of the other.

And therefore let me freely in≈øert this important and nece≈ø≈øary Caution for England, That they take heed they do not overdo their work; and ≈øo far irritate this Republick, that out of a pre≈øent prejudice and pa≈ø≈øion, and al≈øo de≈øperation of their future quietne≈øs from them, they call in the French, to be revenged of them, though it be to their own ruine.

I know many are jealous, that this whole War is onely to make the Prince of Orange a Monarch, and the two Crowns will have no more to do with the States; although I profe≈øs, I am far from thinking, that tho≈øe two Kings and Kingdoms would be at all this expence of blood and trea≈øure for that end onely, and doe believe that if that would ≈øet us in our former condition, it would ≈øoone be a≈ø≈øented unto, not onely by the multitude, but the wi≈øeft men among≈øt us, who know the extraordinary abilities and great capacities of his Highne≈øs. Therefore let me ≈øay it freely without offence, either of Him or his Enimies, that I perceive many lay this for a
fundamental maxim, Better a Prince that hath power to defend us, then one whom we mu≈øt onely defend. And except my eye-≈øight fail me, ≈øome are fa≈øt at work in preparing materials to build thereon. A word is enough to the wi≈øe, and therefore I will ≈øay no more.

Nay I will not di≈ø≈øemble my further fears, That if France keeps tho≈øe places on the South Sea, and ≈øhould get others lower, either in Holland or Frie≈ølands, as may capacitate him to incommodate their Trade, though we ≈øhould have a peace for ≈øome time with him, we ≈øhall fall into his hands at la≈øt. For the French are already ≈øo near us on every ≈øide, that they hover over us, as a Hawk over the grey, watching onely an opportunity, how they may gra≈øp us in their talons.
If any ≈øhall here aske me, Why may we not then as well now become French?

I al≈øo ≈øhall aske ≈øuch one Que≈øtion, which when they ≈øatisfie me in, I al≈øo ≈øhall them. You know certainly you mu≈øt die at la≈øt, (whereas here is onely uncertaine fears) and yet when you are ≈øick, why do you take phy≈øick and u≈øe means for recovery? Is it not becau≈øe you de≈øire to live as long as you can? Doe you not account him a mad man, that will ca≈øt away his life, although he mu≈øt lo≈øe it at the la≈øt? And rightly, becau≈øe who knows what God may doe, and whether he may not recover him, though the di≈øea≈øe be de≈øperate?

Having ≈øpoke our thoughts concerning the≈øe united, we ≈øhall now ≈øpeak of the Spani≈øh Provinces. I have as much ≈ømattering skill in Phy≈øick, I confe≈øs, as would ≈øerve me to make Charon a fraight of old Wives; yet am I far from being arrived at the confidence, which I have ob≈øerved in ∆≤rinal-Doctors. And yet for once, I will adventure to try the little skill I have, with tho≈øe State-Mountebanks, that are ≈øo ≈øecure concerning the Spani≈øh Netherlands. For my part, I have ≈øhak't their Water again and again, and can find nothing but ≈øymptoms of death. I ≈øhall onely premi≈øe that I ≈øhall not with an Emperical confidence tell you the time: Kingdoms and States, as well as private per≈øons, ≈øometimes langui≈øh out rather then live their la≈øt. But that they are ≈øo ≈øick, that I ≈øee no hopes of their recovery if this War continues. And I will tell you my feares for the en≈øuing Summer.
1. The incredible preparations that France makes this Winter, both of Men and Money, as if they would ≈øet all at ≈øtake for carrying on the following Summers Wars.

2. The Empire's Army is overmatcht with Turens. They know, that we are not in a capacity to recover the Cities we have lo≈øt, and that they cannot conquer tho≈øe that remaine; ≈øo that their Armies cannot be de≈øigned either for ≈øtrengthning their owne Garri≈øons, or forcing of ours. Except they will ≈øpend a Summers Expedition upon ≈øome incon≈øiderable out Garri≈øons, which I cannot imagin.

3. I have looked round about in Europe, where this ≈øtorme ≈øhould fall,
and can ≈øee no place it hovers over, except tho≈øe Provinces, and our ≈øelves.
4. I con≈øider the eminent advantage France hath at pre≈øent by their friend≈øhip with England; which I feare he will take.

5. Allthough I doe not thinke France will prevaile by all his endeavors with England to breake with Spaine; yet I thinke England will either be employed in doing their owne worke, or not ≈øo quickly breake with France, to ≈øtop his carriere in over-running tho≈øe Netherlands.

6 We ≈øhall either have the Wars continue, or a Peace. If the former as they are, though England helps not therein, (for they profes in their Declaration to maintaine the Treaty at Aken) yea, though they would hinder it, yet I doe not ≈øee how they can practically, if they have not prevented it beforehand by their Treaty; nor we to be ≈øure the Wars continuing. If a Peace be concluded, we ≈øhall be forced to for≈øake them; this being the main ground of the quarrel. For if we would have helped France to have ruind them, we might have been quiet for ≈øome time at lea≈øt; but becau≈øe we had rather quench, then ≈øet our neighbors hou≈øe on fire, le≈øt ours follow in the flames: France hath fallen upon us, and ≈øhall we not then thinke that he will cudgell us into ≈øuch conditions? It is true indeed, if England and we come to under≈øtand one another, and our joynt intre≈øt better; we may ≈øuccor them for ≈øome time; but that's not my ≈øuppo≈øal, of the Wars continuing as they are, which in that ca≈øe implies a ≈øtrange complication of di≈øea≈øes, which to me, who knows not their Treaty, ≈øeems incurable.

7. And where el≈øe they ≈øhould have a≈ø≈øi≈øtance to ≈øave them, if France will fall upon them, I ≈øee not. For the Empire cannot, it is well if they can ≈øave them≈øelves. Spaine is at a great di≈øtance. May make perhaps ≈øome diver≈øion in Catalonia, or ≈øome ≈ømall from Millan, &c. But whats that to ≈øave tho≈øe Provinces?

8. We mu≈øt therefore con≈øider if they can ≈øtand on their owne legs, ≈øo as to with≈øtand their enimies power, and not to be throwne downe thereby. And here we ≈øhall find the number of Spani≈øh incon≈øiderable; the Dutch very wavering and uncertaine: Some Popi≈øh Zealots thinking France can be≈øt carry on their de≈øignes; others betwixt hopes and feares, wi≈øhing they might ≈øee an i≈ø≈øue; and others plainely de≈øpairing of re≈øi≈øtance, de≈øiring they were over. Their Cities great and untenable, ≈øeverall of them requiring allmo≈øt as many to man them well, as they have Spani≈øh in the Countrey. If they can make good Bruxels, Antwerp, Namur, and Oo≈øtend, for ≈øome time, to ≈øee if the affaires of Europe may not alter, it is all I expect. But what ≈øhall become of the whole Countrey, and the re≈øt of the Cities,De≈øcriptio Lovani. Bruges, Mechlin, Gant, Lovaine, &c. Some of them as large as mo≈øt Cities in Europe. Three Noblemen An. 1427. (as Guicciardine tells us) with great charges, had five of the greate≈øt Cities on this ≈øide the Alpes mea≈øured, and found but, 18 Rods or Perches difference. Of which Lovaine and Gant, the greate≈øt; Paris (within the Walls) and Liege alike; Colen the lea≈øt. But neglecting to mention the ju≈øt mea≈øure, Guicciardine tells us they

And here many perhaps will thinke me litle better than madd, to cro≈øs the current opinion of Chri≈øtendom; when I ≈øay that the Friend≈øhip of France and England is ≈øick at heart, and cannot live long; and the contrary of that betwene England and Spaine. When all Europe ≈øtood in doubt what England would doe, and all men on

The Saturday morning early after the fight, the Fi≈øcale ≈øent his footman to tell me they had fought, with ≈øome generalls thereof, and that the Fleet was before the Land: I mu≈øt confes, I ≈øtood amazed at Holmes's furious folly, who had orders onely to bring them up, not to commence a War, the Declaration thereof being not publi≈øhed; allthough to tho≈øe that would not ≈øubmit to ≈øuch orders, it was all one in effect, though not in formalities, which are the greate≈øt plea, that I know of, that the Engli≈øh have for that Action. Upon this I began to con≈øider the Rea≈øons of State as to England, both dome≈øtick and forreign; For I rea≈øoned thus, if this friend≈øhip be ≈øo firme that England will goe through with France in all their great de≈øignes, I mu≈øt make other mea≈øures then I had formerly done. Whil≈øt I am bu≈øy in ballancing all the Rea≈øons of State for tho≈øe Kingdoms, and likewi≈øe for their Intre≈øt abroad as comprehen≈øively as I could, the Prote≈øtants Intre≈øt, the Triple Alliance, the greatnes of France, the danger of England &c. comes the Engli≈øh Declaration of War to mine hands, but without a particular date, contrary to practi≈øe, but wi≈øely to colour what Holmes had done. The Fleet wherein the Engli≈øh had the principall ≈øhare of power and command, onely faced ours at fir≈øt in point of Honour, yet attacqued them not, though they had the wind, whereby they might ea≈øily have done it at their plea≈øure, and al≈øo to their Advantage; but ≈øtood over againe to the Engli≈øh coa≈øt. div.head: Sect. 12. France's Ambition. Crowing greatnes. The cau≈øe thereof. We and England in the fault. div.p: And indeed ≈øuch is the growing greatnes of that Kingdome, that it is become formidable to all Europe. I need not in≈øi≈øt on this the World is ≈øufficiently ≈øen≈øible of it; but it may be worth our pains to enquire into the cau≈øes thereof.

France formerly had ≈øeverall boundaries to their Ambition, which by degrees they have broken downe. Severall Dukes, on the one ≈øide that of Normandie, Comines, 1, 6. c. 3. and the Engli≈øh after who for 400 years together lat√® dominati ≈øunt in Gallia; till Charles the 7. his time; and that of Bretagnie, till Charles the 8 gained it to the Crowne of France, by the marriage of Anne, Daughter of Francis the 2. the la≈øt Duke thereof; and on the other ≈øide the Dukes of Bungundie, till Lewis the 11. who after the death of Charles the la≈øt Duke ≈ølaine at the Battell of Nancey, ≈øeized thereon, and united it to the Crowne of France. The≈øe three Potentates kept the French Kings continually under, by their Confederations and Wars again≈øt that Kingdome. Which Bands, they having once broke, they became at liberty to get more elbow-room in the World; and become the large≈øt, compacte≈øt, and ≈øtronge≈øt Kingdom of Europe, were it not that their owne inte≈øtine Divi≈øions, and frequent Civil Wars hath often weakned them.

After France had arrived at this greatnes, the following Kings Charles the 8. Lewis the 12. and Francis the fir≈øt, fruitle≈øly ≈øpent the Kingdoms ≈øtrength in their Wars in Italy; till Francis and Charles the 5. became competitors for the Empire, and Spaine and France a fit match for each other in power. Since which time ≈øuch mighty conte≈øts have been betwixt tho≈øe two Kingdoms, as have filled all Europe with terror and amazement, and all Hi≈øtorians with their Actions. But how France hath ≈øo far prevailed, as we ≈øee at pre≈øent, is partly by our owne, and partly by the Engli≈øh fault; we by Commi≈ø≈øion, and they by Omi≈ø≈øion, as we ≈øhall (with what brevity
we can) make apparent, in regard it may be u≈øefull to us both.

The≈øe two Cromwel, and the Cardinal the ≈øtronglier to carry on their de≈øignes, take in the King of Sweden for a third into their confederacy (Chri≈øtina having re≈øigned that Crowne, and wandring about like a blazing Comet) and the≈øe three Leagued together made the Triumvirate of tho≈øe times.

Sweden was to pluck the plumes of the Roman Eagle, when he had clipt the wings of his Neighbours, that they might not fly upon the prey he left
behind. Wherein Oliver ≈øo concerned him≈øelf, that when the Dane had got the Dutch for his ≈øecond, he ≈øent Montague to boye up Swedens ≈øinking intre≈øt in the Sound: and they were ≈øo neere an engagement, that they had certainly fought, had not the Engli≈øh e≈øpied an Advice-Yacht coming towards them, which bringing them newes of the Protectors death, they hoy≈øt up failes, and returnd home.

Who having beene more u≈øed to fight in the field, then play the pioneers with their ≈øpades, were not ≈øo much e≈øteemed at fir≈øt by the French: till the ≈øight with Don John of Au≈øtria's Army which came to relieve Dunkirke, wherein they behaved them≈øelves with that gallantry, that Don John cryed out he was beat by raging wild bea≈øts rather then men; and that great Soldjer the Prince of Conde hath often ≈øaid ≈øince, that he never ≈øaw the like action, as was that day performed by the Engli≈øh Shortly after Dunkerke yielded, and was put into the Engli≈øh hands.

The Protector was to bring downe Spaine by Sea, which he ≈øaid he would do, or he and his ≈øhould live on bread and water. Intending all≈øo to carrie on the de≈øigne, which Sidney, Rawleight and ≈øeveral of the wi≈øe≈øt men of the Indies; but as ≈øhe had too many irons in the fire to carry on that worke, ≈øo how he mi≈øcarried in it, is ≈øufficiently knowne. Admirall Blake, who ≈øtill principled his ≈øeamen in tho≈øe Confu≈øions and frequent Revolutions of Government, that the Fleet ≈øerved no Parties nor Per≈øons, but the Engli≈øh Nation; having brought ≈øome of his great ≈øhips before Tunis, batterd down the Ca≈øtle and compeld them to his termes; for which extraordinary ≈øervice he expected the reward of gratitude at lea≈øt: In ≈øtead thereof, by his next Advice from England he hath a pardon ≈øent him, for endangering, the Fleet in ≈øuch an attempt without order, &c. Which ≈øo ≈øtuck on the ≈øtomack of that ≈øtout and ≈øturdy Stoick, that afterwards the Spani≈øh Fleet coming on the maine Ocean off Cadiz; He reading his Commi≈ø≈øion, and finding it onely for fighting them in the Mediterranean, would not fall on them, though the Commanders Sollicited him, promi≈øed to an≈øwer it for him, &c. onely was willing to fight if the Spanjards begun; but though the Engli≈øh provoked them to it, and affronted them all they could, yet the wary Spanjard was wi≈øer then to ingage, and ≈øo ≈øaved them≈øelves; at which Oliver ≈øtormed not a litle, but Blake cared not much, the Admirall heereby crying quits with the Generall.

Thus you ≈øee what great things a little blind zeale may doe. And indeed it is not ≈øo much to be admired at in him, he having had ≈øuch an enthu≈øia≈øticall heat, as all know, that knew him well; nor can we wonder ≈øo much, if his head ≈øometimes run round, who was ≈øo continually wrapt up in
≈øuch whirlepooles of affaires, as he was perpetually plunged in: though to mi≈øcarry in ≈øo great a concernment for the Prote≈øtant Intre≈øt, was a capitall crime in him above all others; who de≈øigning to pul down the Pope, Grotius de jure bel. & pac. l. 2. c. 22. voluntatem implondi vaticinia, ≈øine Dei, mandato, non e≈ø≈ø√® cau≈øam bellit by bringing downe Spaine, ≈øet up France to ruine the Protestants throughout Chri≈øtendome. Thus Ludit in humanis divina potentia rebus!

But the≈øe three lived not long to goe on with the≈øe de≈øignes, and indeed it was well for the world they did not. But to be briefe, Olivers other two Con≈øorts followed after him quickly, and the≈øe three Conquerors, being cut of by death, who kept all Chri≈øtendome in aw whil≈øt they lived, the world had a little quiet, till France got a hor≈øeback again in Flanders.

But betwixt and that time was that great change in England by the wonderfull providence of God in the re≈øtoration of his Maje≈øty, by which meanes the French got Dunkirke again into their hands, and were therby capacitated, the better to carry on their worke again≈øt the≈øe Countries. Atwhich the French made them≈øelves merry, and ≈øome ≈øay abu≈øively, by having Dunkirke drawn with a pur≈øe hanging over it: The Engli≈øh ≈øtormed, and ≈øome ≈øwore Oliver would have ≈øold his great no≈øe, rather then Dunkerke. Yea this ≈øtill ≈øticks on many of their ≈øtomachs; I remember at my la≈øt being in England in 66, and ≈øeeing Clarenden Hou≈øe; and wondring a little why it was ≈øituated ≈øo neer the roade, which made it both unfree, and mole≈øted with du≈øt; and criti≈øing upon ≈øome other things, the Oratory e≈øpecially, that the Chancelor that was the elde≈øt Son of the Church of England, ≈øhould make his Chappel, as a wag writ of Emanuel Colledge's, ≈øo awry: Ju≈øt North and South, yea verily: when I came above on the leads I was ≈øo plea≈øed with
the plea≈øantnes of the pro≈øpect, that I thought for that it might compare with any Hou≈øe I had ≈øeen, knowing no place in England except above Greenwich, that I thought comparable to it, upon which the dome≈øtick had the confidence, perceiving me a ≈øtranger, to tell me I could not thence ≈øee Dunkirke; for the Commonality had Chri≈øtened it, and made Dunkirke the Godfather, calling the Hou≈øe after its name. But though I confe≈øs it was again≈øt the Common Intre≈øt of Europe, that it ≈øhould fall to the French againe; yet whether it was again≈øt the Intre≈øt of the King of England, and that Kingdome, is not ≈øo cleare to me. I will onely ≈øay this, that I know a per≈øon hath weighed that ≈øo well, that I ≈øhall carry this challenge for him, That if any Gentleman, Engli≈øh or French, plea≈øes fairely to ≈øtate this Que≈øtion in hypothe≈øi, according to the circum≈øtances of tho≈øe times, let him take which ≈øide thereof he plea≈øes, and u≈øe what weapons he will (and I think thats very faire) and he ≈øhall not want an Antagoni≈øt, that ≈øhall fight him fairely, whether he plea≈øes to appeare in Roman buf, or in his halfe ≈øhirt made of his owne mothers language, upon the publick Theater of the World. Having thus ≈øhewne the true State of France, and its continuall growing greatnes downe to the times of his pre≈øent Maje≈øty, who hath not onely got Dunkirke, regained Lorraigne, conquered a great part of Flanders from the Spani≈øh but three Provinces all≈øo entirely from the States: It will clearely follow to be the Common Intre≈øt of Europe to oppo≈øe France in their future progre≈øs, except they meane to follow our fate.

I had thought to have been larger heerein then I ≈øhall, in regard my paines is heerein in part prevented, by the Authour of la France Politique from page 470 to 525, or the end: And having been ≈øo long allready, I may happily hereafter, di≈øcour≈øe this more largely in another language. Impius haec tam culta novalia miles habebit,
Barbarus has ≈øegetes!

And though Liege (or Luyke) be great and populous, and the de≈øperate≈øt people in all times, that I know in Europe; yet vana e≈øt ≈øine viribus ira, the City hath ≈øuch hills overhanging it, that it is neither ≈øtrong by its ≈øituation, nor can hope of relief if they ≈øhould be di≈øtre≈ø≈øed, except it be by a confederacy from others; and if this ≈øingle City be lo≈øt, all their Country will be ≈øo quickly.

This Republick of all others is mo≈øt immediately concerned, for he is blind that ≈øees not, whatever ≈øome may flatter them≈øelves, that the French intend nothing les then reducing of us to their obedience.

And when this is done, and they advance upwards in the Empire; what are Stratsburg, Colen, Aken, Breme, Hamburg, and the re≈øt of the Han≈øe
Townes, and free Cities, but as ≈øo many mor≈øels, ea≈øily eaten up and devoured?

Sweden how they will ≈øave their Bi≈øhoprick of Breme, Pomeren, and what lies on this ≈øide the Baltick: and how they will ≈øell their Copper, which is the Staple commodity of their owne Countrey. And in ≈øtead of the French Crownes, which is now their u≈øuall money among≈øt them; when that Kingdome hath no more neede of their ≈øervice; they may carry their owne Copper coyne on their backs to pay a collation, or laden a hor≈øe when they travel, to pay for 2 or 3 good nights lodging.

Savoy knows he is at France's mercy, and therefore dances after their pipe, endeavouring to ≈øave him≈øelfe by his devotion. For Switzerland, though their mountaines and Poverty may ≈øecure perhaps their Countrey: yet what ≈øhall ≈øecure their liberty, which con≈øi≈øts in an equality among≈øt them? or what ≈øhall ≈øecure the. And thus you ≈øee what nece≈ø≈øity there is that the French be kept within bounds: and con≈øequently. that the ballance of Europe, be both brought and held in a greater equality. For intre≈øts changing continually with the revolution of times; and Kingdoms and Commonwealths, Cities and places, having their youth ≈øtrength and old age, as well as particular per≈øons: If le≈ø≈øer Powers combine not together, they ≈øingly become like the ≈ømaller fi≈øhes, ea≈øily ≈øwallowed up and devoured by the greater. Thus the league between the King of Naples,
Lib. 1. Duke of Millain and Florence A. D. 1480. ≈øecured Italy again≈øt the power of the Venctians; and the Confederacy of the Italians at Venice in 95, pre≈øerved them from being all ruind by the French under Charles the 8, who had in a ≈ømall time conquered ≈øeverall, and got the Kingdome of Naples he came for: Lib. 2. as that wi≈øe Hi≈øtorian Guicciardine ≈øhews, in his excellent Hi≈øtorie of the Wars of Italie.
Nor let any thinke to ob≈øtruct my pa≈ø≈øage with ≈øaying, that Wars to bring downe the growing greatnes of others are unlawfull.

For though very many both Lawiers and Hi≈øtorians are of the opinion they are,De jure belli l. 1. c. 14. as may be ≈øeene in Gentilis, and ≈øome Divines all≈øo, yea the whole Colledge of Sorben gave their determination for this, and the Learned Bacon E≈ø≈øay (or ≈øermo fidelis) 19. ≈øaies plainely that the contrary opinion is not to be received, and many other moderne Authors concur heerein, be≈øides the many Precedents of States that have made preventive Wars, as the Lacedemonians again≈øt the
Arhenians of old, and many e≈øpecially of later times; and the Arguments for it are not contemptible: yet notwith≈øtanding I am rather of Grotius's opinion,De jure belli & pac. l. 2. c. 1. ¬ß. 17. &c. 22. ¬ß. 5. that neither our owne feares and jealou≈øies, nor the growing greatnes of others, are ≈øufficient cau≈øes of warring again≈øt them.
But indeed neither of the≈øe is the cau≈øe we plead, but the following, which we will maintaine jure gentium or by the law of Nations to be ju≈øt and equitable.

1. Let any Kingdome or Common-wealth grow as great, as they can by Gods ble≈ø≈øing; yet ≈øo long as they keep them≈øelves, within the bounds of ju≈øtice and equity with others; there is no ju≈øt cau≈øe of breaking downe their power by War. For jealou≈øie that we may thereby ≈øuffer, is no ≈øufficient ground for us to fight them. And therefore again≈øt ≈øuch force as we may feare, we mu≈øt tru≈øt the Providence of God, and u≈øe lawfull meanes cautiou≈øly to prevent dangers; our Saviour having taught all Chri≈øtians to u≈øe the wi≈ødome of the Serpent with the innocencie of the dove, and cur≈øed be they that ≈øeperates, what Chri≈øt hath joyned together.

2. When Neighbor Nations ≈øee the growing power of any, whence they have ju≈øt cau≈øe of jealou≈øie: they ought to combine together; that ≈øo they may prevent the dangers they feare. And if any of the Confederates be unju≈øtly invaded, they have all a ju≈øt cau≈øe of War again≈øt the Agre≈ø≈øor. As the Italians being jealous of the Venetians Power,Guicciardine's Hi≈øt. of Ital. l. 1. leagued them≈øelves for their owne defence, ≈øo that though the Republick of Venice was too ≈øtrong for any of them ≈øingly, yet being far too weake for them all, was kept within bounds, and they thereby wi≈øely ≈øecured them≈øelves.

3. When any Potentate that is ≈øtronger then his Neighbors aggre≈ø≈øes any of them, the re≈øt ought to Confederate; and if his cau≈øe be ju≈øt compell him to accept of due ≈øatisfaction, and if he will not, his cau≈øe then becoming unju≈øt, and much more if it was ≈øo originally, to make War again≈øt him. As the Italians did again≈øt the French, when they under Charles the 8 were invaded. And the Triple Alliance of late, when the ≈øame nation had taken the County of Burgundie, commonly called the French Comt√© and invaded Flanders, both which belong to the Crowne of Spaine. Thus our Neighbors all≈øo ≈øhould now allie with us, in point of hone≈øt intre≈øt; that ≈øo we may reduce France to keepe within bounds, le≈øt we ≈øhould all be ruind by them.

I ≈øhall make the≈øe things plaine by familiar example. The ballancing of Nations is like to that of boats: they that by an even poize, might all ≈øit ≈øafe in a boate on a rough Sea, by the ri≈øing up of ≈øome are all in danger to be drowned. In ≈øuch ca≈øe therefore the company perceiving, a quarrel likely to ari≈øe among≈øt ≈øome of them, mu≈øt either agree before hand to keepe them quiet; or if the conte≈øt come ≈øuddenly, afterwards re≈øolve together, to compel tho≈øe that are injurious, to keepe their place; and if

1. By the Confederacy of weaker Nations that are their Neighbors, and are in danger thereby of being overcome, as we have allready ≈øhewne.

And this was the Ancient policy of England, Memoires de Ribier T. 1. l. 2. l. 347. Memoires de du Ple≈ø≈øis. Memoire du Duc de Sulli, T. 2. c. 4. p. 14. Amba≈ø≈øades du Cardinal O≈ø≈øat part. 1. p. 180. Annales Eliz. A. 1577. ≈øince France and Spaine became the two great ballances in Europe. Which (as I have ≈øaid) begun to be ≈øo under Charles the 5, and Francis the fir≈øt, whom Henry the 8 of England ≈øtill kept even, as the many Hi≈øtories of tho≈øe times ≈øhew, as well as other writers of State affaires, engraving this motto upon his Gold, Cui adhaereo, praee≈øt. From this maxim of State Q. Elizabeth, all≈øo his Daughter, fir≈øt a≈ø≈øi≈øted Henry the 4, which Mornay ≈øtrongly pleaded to Wal≈øingham; and after when France was growne great, a≈ø≈øi≈øted the≈øe Provinces, le≈øt they ≈øhould fall into the hands of France; as we have before ≈øhewne out of the be≈øt Hi≈øtorians of tho≈øe times, Thuanus and Cambden, the latter whereof after his declaring this rea≈øon of State in the place formentioned A. 1575, afterwards ≈øhews how this noble Heroine ≈øate as the honourable Arbitratrix, (holding the ballance in her hands) between Spaine, France, and the≈øe Low Countries.

div.head: Sect. 13. The Conclu≈øion of the whole Di≈øcour≈øe.
div.p: I Have now done, and it is high time, having been much larger then I intended at fir≈øt; allthough not ≈øo large by far, as I found, being once entred upon the Argument, I might be. And yet, I hope, it will not be tedious to the Reader. Inregard of the novelty of the matter, which though daily di≈øcour≈øt of by many yet never writ of by any. And in regard of the u≈øefulnes thereof. For though old men are apt to dote upon the brats of their brain, as well as their body: Yet, if I be not deceived, this Di≈øcour≈øe, may through Gods ble≈ø≈øing, prove in≈øtrumentall in begetting a better under≈øtanding between both Nations, (for which end I have publi≈øhed it in both Languages) by ≈øhewing them their concernments, it being the Chariot of Intre≈øt which all Princes and States Jehu-like furiou≈øly drive; and all≈øo ≈øerve to cleare up ≈øome State Controver≈øies, that are not ea≈øily di≈øcerned by vulgar eyes, to di≈øcover the former and pre≈øent ≈øtate of affaires among≈øt us, and mo≈øt parts of Europe, and give a pro≈øpect through this intricate, darke, and cloudy War, with what hopes we may have concerning its i≈ø≈øue: And be≈øides the≈øe things, I thinke the clearnes of ≈øtile, which I have u≈øed to deliver my minde in, may make it bes nautious to ≈øome, who are apt to mind the ≈øwadling cloths more then the Child.

I know medation betwixt men in pa≈ø≈øion is a very thankles office; and that the freedome I have u≈øed, will both plea≈øe and di≈øplea≈øe many ≈øorts of men on all ≈øides; but yet when mens pa≈ø≈øions are allayed, I doe not doubt but they will thinke better of the hone≈øt de≈øignes of the Author. And yet I have endeavoured to give as little offence as I could po≈ø≈øibly to any; but if any notwith≈øtanding count me their enimie, becau≈øe I tell them the truth, I cannot helpe it: for I never accounted them worthy to write, that are by a≈øt with feare, or favour and flattery. Yea, I per≈øwade my ≈øelfe, that there is not any ingenuous man, or brave Gentleman even of the French Nation, who≈øe de≈øignes I cheifly oppo≈øe; but they will acknowledge it lawfull for an enimie, to fight them with a pen as well as a pike, and that I am a very civil Adver≈øary, having both fairely fought them, and with their owne weapons, having made u≈øe of their Authors, and not ours, throughout my di≈øcour≈øe.

I ≈øhall not now throw downe the gantlet and make a challenge, yet if any undertake to refute me concerning the intre≈øt of the≈øe Countries, which I thinke worthy an≈øwering, I ≈øhall not faile to doe it. As for my Conjectures, I both account and call them probable, and therfore being not po≈øitive and dogmaticall in them, I leave them with their Rea≈øons to the Reader to judge. But if ≈øome pa≈ø≈øionate per≈øon thinks with railing at the French, Engli≈øh, or the Author hereof, and carping at ≈øome particulars to refute me; I ≈øhall tell them before hand I was never bred, to give any one ill language, and ≈øhall onely an≈øwer them with ≈øilence and contempt. Or if any well meaning ≈øcholler that hath read perhaps hone≈øt Keckermans, or ≈øome others learned Sy≈øtema Politicum; I ≈øhall onely ≈ømile in my ≈øleeve, having allwayes accounted Booke policy alone, mere pedantry; and allthough no man valew's learning more then my ≈øelfe, yet he mu≈øt know men as well as bookes, and the world well, that will write of the≈øe things. Yet if any will bring Rea≈øons of State, and clearely delivered, as I thinke I have done, and fairely ventilate my opinion, I ≈øhall promi≈øe him as faire an An≈øwer, for truth never feared a faire tryall.

div.head: POSTSCRIPT.
div.p: It is nece≈ø≈øary that I tell you, this worke bath been long in the birth. I had drawne up my thoughts on this ≈øubject the la≈øt yeare, and ≈øent my Papers into Holland to print; but my hone≈øt friends unacquainted with the Artifice of Governement, to nouri≈øh hopes in the greate≈øt dangers (Hope being the mi≈øerable mans God, as well as the pre≈øumptuous mans Devil) ≈øent me word, of nothing but peace, yet kept my Papers through curio≈øity, till I was forced to ≈øend my ≈øervant for them. And baring got them, and contracted with a Printer here, He was called out for a Soldjer, and goe he mu≈øt, and therefore the worke mu≈øt ≈øtand. In the meane time two ≈øorts of Papers came to mine hands, The Appeale; which, though his de≈øigne, in reference to England, be different from mine, yet in reference to France, being much the ≈øame, I let pas for the pre≈øent; and the Chancelor of Englands ≈øpeech, with his Defenda e≈øt Carthago, which whil≈øt my Printer after his returne home is printing off this, I examined, according to the Rules of Chri≈øtian Charity, Common Equity, and State Policy; but that being too large, I re≈øerve it for an Appendix. In the meane time, though it be late before this comes forth (the Moneth of April 73.) yet I hope better late then never; and though no Printer well undertake it, becau≈øe it is Paradoxical to the common opinion of Peace, yet I have put it into the publick Trea≈øury for good, at my owne charge in both Languages; and though it co≈øt me 100 l and none con≈øider me, or to u≈øe Solomons phra≈øe, Remember that poore man, in any kind, not ≈øo much as to enquire after him, or returne him thanks; yet it ≈øhall not repent me for the good of both Nations, for which I intend it, and to whom I wi≈øh a happy peace, and all pro≈øperity.
